story: The rise of the populist KPV LV party has spooked the West because its leader Artuss Kaimins, whose popularity soared as he railed against political corruption, has refused to rule out an alliance with the pro-Russian Harmony party which has been branded a potential EU &rsquoTrojan Horse&rsquo.The party, whose main support comes from Latvia's ethnic Russian minority, won most seats at the last election but was sidelined from power when mainstream parties refused to include it in any deal due to its ties with the Kremlin.It holds 24 out of the 100 seats in parliament and recently rebranded itself as a Western-style Social Democratic party, saying it is committed to the EU and NATO.But it only ended its official co-operation agreement with Mr Putin's United Russia Party last year, raising concerns in the West that its transformation is only skin deep.                'EU will NOT split' Latvian minister warns no deal Brexit now 5050                Brexit latest news: Latvia urges EU to keep strong ties with BritainAndis Kudors, executive director of the Centre for East European Policy Studies, warned Harmony could still be used by Russia to influence EU affairs if it rose to power in partnership with the KPV LV.He said: Harmony is like a kind of Trojan horse in the EU when we speak about common EU foreign policy in regards to Russia.The KPV backs EU and NATO membership, but its vague election programme has left many wondering what could happen if it takes power.Mr Kaimins has said he is open to working with Harmony if it condemns Russia's role in the conflict in eastern Ukraine and drops demands for Russian-language education in Latvian schools.NATO troops on manoeuvres in Latvia (Image: )KPV LV party leader Artuss Kaimins (Image: )Harmony has not ruled out working with any party and has said KPVs voters will have to be respected.Prime Minister Maris Kucinskis, of the Union of Greens and Farmers party, warned: We are at a crossroads. Either we will form a new government or they will.&ldquoA KPV-Harmony ruling alliance would represent a rather radical change of Latvia's position towards the European Union and towards our security matters which, I think, is very dangerous.Mr Kucinskis' conservative government coalition looks well short of winning a majority in Sunday&rsquos elections with recent polls suggesting Harmony will remain the biggest party, followed by the Union of Greens and Farmers and Mr Kaimins' KPV LV.                Russia news: Moscow&rsquos tests are a &lsquodemonstration of force&rsquo                 EU COLLAPSE: Putin preying on 'WEAK' Europe as targets EU membersLatvia is an EU and NATO member state with a 167-mile border with Russia and is a key ally in the increasingly hostile relationship between the West and President Vladimir Putin.More than 1,000 NATO troops are based in the Baltic country and even the potential of a minor shift in allegiance in Latvia has set alarm bills ringing in Brussels and Washington.

title: more young people are feeling lonely
story: The Eleanor Rigby of Beatles legend: “All the lonely people, where do they all come from ”An answer emerged this week — and they come from a surprising place.The loneliest people are healthy, thriving young adults, kicking off their career and probably renting a room in a city.According to new university research for the BBC, levels of loneliness are highest among  to -year-olds, with  per cent saying they often, or very often, feel it. In contrast, the over-s are positively chipper: Only  per cent of this group reported feelings of isolation.Now, I’m  and, depressingly, these statistics don’t surprise me.At first glance, it looks like young people have it easy when it comes to making friends.At  or thereabouts, more than  per cent of them will be packed off to university where they’ll move in with a group of like-minded people of the same age and be encouraged to drink and party like there’s no tomorrow.Which, when you’re only required to stumble out of bed for one pm lecture, there essentially isn’t.Rather than relying on friends of tenuous friends for dubious introductions, young people these days can simply download an app and get the details of thousands of eligible strangers delivered straight to their mobile phones.Add into the mix social media ­— which allows its users to connect with everyone they’ve ever met instantaneously at any given moment — and it’s hard to imagine how any young people could possibly be lonely, let alone  per cent.But there are two sides to every coin.University — though a godsend when it comes to meeting new people — can be a problem when it comes to staying in touch with them. Saddled with bottomless debt, young graduates simply don’t have the cash to socialise.When a round for six at a London pub will set you back  quid, is it any wonder that more and more young people are opting to stay at home Dating apps, too, come with their pitfalls. Yes, it’s nice to have a database of singletons in your pocket, but the ubiquity of Tinder and Bumble mean it’s now considered almost socially awkward to speak to someone you fancy in person.A friend of mine, who has absolutely no problem propositioning women on Tinder, hasn’t yet found the courage to ask for his next-door neighbour’s number, four months after she moved in.As for social media, young people like me are increasingly discovering that “staying connected” is a mixed blessing at best. With no excuse to lose touch, my generation holds on to friends we’ve outgrown, leaving us with no time to make new ones. It may sound callous, but there’s an art to shedding friends, and thanks to our social media addiction, we seem to have lost it.What’s more, earnest  to -year-olds seem to be taking to heart the faddish health advice that adults have been merrily ignoring for years, making it even harder for them to socialise because they fear alcohol, and even food.At the end of a recent party I got chatting to a fun young woman, so I suggested some pub grub at a boozer to round off the evening. How wrong I was.She explained in detail she was vegan and on a gluten-free diet , so the pub menu would not cater for her needs.I decided not to pursue it.So I say it’s time snowflake millennials took a bit of responsibility for their own feelings of isolation.Last month commentators wagged their fingers at the big tech companies after a survey by charity YoungMinds revealed a greater number of young people view social media as having a negative impact on the way they feel about themselves than those who report a positive impact.But it was never suggested depressed young people should simply put away their phones and do something .Mollycoddled millennials believe having a thriving social circle is a human right, rather than an ongoing project.Instead of popping to the pub for a pick-me-up with whoever happens to be around, a lonely young person will all too often turn to the internet for a spot of indulgent self-reflection, or to the gym for Insta-friendly self-improvement.As a result, pubs are closing at a rate of  a day, and sites such as Tumblr are overflowing with posters instructing users to “forget the haters” and “shine like the star that you are”.Of course, social media is made to be addictive. But surely putting down a phone can’t be an insurmountable challenge for an educated generation of young people  Dwelling on yourself is the surest route to a lonely lestyle, so instead of posting doleful, introspective memes on social media or clinging to tired old friendships, lonely young people should find the guts to get outside and look outwards.Making and keeping real friends takes work, and it’s time young people started putting the hours in.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: life on street where hookers beg school run dads for 30 alleyway romps and say rush hours our best time
story: Young women - wearing mini dresses and stilettos - openly tout for business in front of primary schoolkids as dawn breaks over Hassle Road in Hull, East Yorkshire.Loitering near bus stops and outside shops, they offer passers-by cheaper rates for sex outdoors.One told The Sun Online am is the peak time because: “Its rush hour, babe.”Locals warn the grim situation is now intolerable, with the number of women patrolling the street rocketing.On Friday morning, one sex worker approached our reporter as kids walked to one of the seven nearby primary schools today.Dressed in tight jeans and a black leather jacket, the dark haired girl in her late s, begged: Do you want business ”Asked why she was out in broad daylight, she replied: “It’s rush hour babe. It’s the best time.When everyone is going to work. Have you got a car  It’s £ for sex or £ for a [sex act].Another sex worker, aged around , offered our reporter full outdoor sex for £.She said: “Do you want business  Do you want it indoors or outdoors  It’s £ for sexyou want to go back to my flat.“If you want it outdoors it’s £ for oral sex or £ for sex. Theres an alley just around the corner.I will be here for a bit babe - butI get another job I will be gone.“There’s a cash point just across the road or at the garage. Where are you parked  It’s best in a car.She then whispered that she offered punters the chance to touch her all over for twenty quid.One mum shook her head in despair as she walked her little boy to school.She said: “I work in one of the shops and they are often there when I go to work at eight in the morning after I take my boy to school. It’s terrible.”Meanwhile, other horried locals said they are regularly approached as early as am as they make their way to work.Funeral director Steve Smith, , claims he was solicited while standing at a cash machine before starting work.He told The Sun Online: “I was stood outside the bank and she said: ‘Are you looking for business “I thought that was funny since I am in the funeral business. She was a bit young to end up in a box.“I was wearing my suit and funeral gear and she was dressed in a pair of shorts and a crop top so it was a really bizarre thing to happen at am.Just four years ago, Hull became the first UK city to create a prostitute-free zone, meaning people caught loitering, soliciting or having sex in the area could be arrested and charged.However, the ban has done little to deter the problem, and residents now claim as many as  to  prostitutes tout the streets every day.Newsagent Jo Thirkettle, , said: “They wear skirts like belts, hot pants and other revealing stuff.“They come into the shop asking the customers ‘Do you want business ’ When I tell them to go outside they go after blokes using the cash machine.“They don’t charge very much because people around here can’t afford much anyway.Many of the girls take their customers to an open car park behind the shops which is littered with condoms, cigarette butts, empty beer cans and smashed spirits bottles.Some are even said to be using a disused phone box for sex, often leaving their business cards behind along with condoms, syringes and other drugs paraphernalia.There are seven primary schools within a mile radius of the road - Adelaide, Newington Academy, Hessle Penhurst, Francis Askew, Wheeler, Chiltern and St Georges Primary - as well as two nurseries.A local shop owner, who did not wish to be named, said: There have been prostitutes down here for decades.“They seem to come go – sometimes they are at one end of the street and sometimes at the other.Then they will disappear altogether for a few weeks trying a dferent area. But they always come back.“You’ll see them arguing among themselves about pitches and where they should stand.“I’ve seen them here when I start opening up at am.”Last year, the police launched a clampdown on the notorious spot.Coppers caught  kerb crawlers approaching prostitutes over a three-month period,  of them were then slapped with section  orders, banning them from the area.Councillor Daren Hale insists everything is being done to clampdown on the number of sex workers which “causes misery for residents.”Inspector Kirsty Tock, of the Hull central community policing team, said: “Hessle Road remains our main focus and, at the moment, we are tackling those seeking out sex workers.“We are continuing to carry out patrols and using the injunctions to prevent prostitution on Hull’s streets.“We have changed our approach recently and are using plain-clothes officers and now punters are feeling the full force of these section  orders.We are also using CCTV to collect further evidence.

title: conservative party brexit unity rod liddle opinion
story: I don’t think Theresa May is going to be on Strictly any time soon. Whoever convinced her it would be dead cool to walk on stage at the party conference and jig about to an Abba song needs a bit of invasive brain surgery, right now.It was like a remake of Re-Animator, or Night Of The Living Dead.There’s no point in Theresa trying to tell us she’s the le and soul of the party and actually a bloody good laugh.We know she isn’t. She’s about as charismatic as an underdone crumpet on a wet Sunday. But she doesn’t need to be Ginger Rogers. She’s the Prime Minister.And you have to give her credit for doggedly sticking to that role. EvenI’m not convinced she’s been doing it terribly well.But on Brexit — God, how mind-numbingly boring the whole thing is — she has a good point.I’m not a fan of her Chequers deal for us to leave the European Union. I think we’re giving too much away. I’d rather have a no-deal exit.But time is pressing. And I’m aware that while we Leavers won the referendum, the margin was comparatively small. So we ought to be gracious and accept a little bit of a compromise. Try to strike a respectable deal with those gangsters from insignicant countries.And a little further down the line, tweak the arrangements a little to suit us better. In the meantime, just strike the deal.And that means getting behind May and presenting a united front to Europe. Most of the Conservative MPs understand that, even the arch-Brexiteers like the excellent Michael Gove.But Bfo the Blundering Bear does not. I’m talking about Boris Johnson. Now he IS fun and good company. But he’s about as likely to become Prime Minister as I am to cop off with Emily Ratajkowski after a few pints and a quick meal at the Chicken Cottage.He has very little support among his political colleagues. He has a lot more among Conservative activists. But very little among voters north of Watford.And yet Bfo was at it again this week. Taking the p**s out of the Prime Minister. And making a rousing speech to his hardcore supporters. Demanding we tell the EU to stuff it.Well, there was a time when we should have told the EU to stuff it — two years ago when we first started negotiations.That time has passed. A lack of confidence from the Government and a ided party let us down.Now is the time to show a bit of unity and wring a deal out of the deathly bureaucrats. Maybe not the Chequers deal — May didn’t mention the word at all during her speech — but a version of it.Otherwise we’ll have a General Election on our hands. One the Tories will lose. And you’ll wake up to find John McDonnell is in charge of your finances and Diane Abbott is Home Secretary.Come on — surely that should concentrate the mind a little Hero of the week is Jane Lunnon, head of a girls’ school in South London.She has stuck the boot into “image-obsessed” reality TV – especially that coven of gurning and pouting imbeciles in Love Island, such as Megan Barton Hanson.Such programmes are “incredibly damaging” to young people, she reckons, calling them “trivial nonsense”.I think Jane is right. And the same goes for all those hyped-up talent shows where people with no talent – just a lust for fame – get judged on their appalling performances by people with no talent.Kids need to know the dference between fame for fame’s sake – and real achievement.Its horrible that Corine Remande has lost the sight in one eye after she was hit by a golf ball during the Ryder Cup.The poor woman was standing among spectators when Brooks Koepka’s tee shot hit her in the face.She’s now threatening legal action against the organisers. She says they didn’t give spectators enough protection.This is ludicrous. What were they supposed to do And what will happen is that in future crowds will be kept even further back from the action. Just because of one horrible accident.Wait until the same thing happens in cricket...The uni magazine said: “It was argued that the loud noise of traditional clapping and whooping pose an issue to students with anxiety or sensory issues. BSL clapping – or, jazz hands – would be a more inclusive form of expression.”With anxiety or sensory issues  What is wrong with these people They are “triggered” by almost everything. Especially by people who have views which dfer from their own.That REALLY triggers them. They shouldn’t be at university. They should be safe at home with mummy and daddy.That old windbag Mahathir Mohamad has been visiting the UK.Lovely to have him, of course. He’s the boss of Muslim-dominated Malaysia and he hates Jews.He was at it again over here. Said they all had “hook noses”.And that they were the cause of all the trouble in the Middle East.He’s allowed his view, of course, evenit is one based on hatred and the ideology of his own interpretation of his religion.But how would it beI said Muslims are the cause of most of the trouble in the world I’d be up before the Old Bill for a hate crime before you could say Islamic State.This is because Asian countries are getting more and more wealthy.I suppose this is a good thing. Problem is, I can’t stand them, the middle class.And the thought of nearly four billion people eating avocado on toast while doing Pilates then listening to Coldplay in their Volvo XCs makes me feel terribly queasy.The human race is being taken over by the legions of the smug. Get me outta here.Visitors to the Telford Exotic Zoo were disappointed by the penguins. They just stood, stock still.This is because they are plastic model penguins. The zoo had been unable to get the real thing.And here’s a tip for the zoo owners. Don’t buy any real penguins, stick to the models.I think plastic penguins would be far better suited to an enclosure of a dozen square yards of shingle with a tiny drainage ditch to bathe in.Why are we allowing zoos like this to open  If I were a real penguin in Telford Exotic Zoo I’d sue them. Or beat them about the head with a flipper.Have you seen Vladimir Putin’s new calendar There he is, standing naked in water, muscles rippling, looking stern.Another one has him cuddling a baby leopard.I hate to say this but isn’t it all a bit... um... camp And now for saying this I’ll probably end up resembling one of the glow sticks the kids buy at funfairs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rooting against cashless britain
story: But in just ten years’ time, kids will find the idea of a porcelain container for metal coins ridiculous — and will be doing their saving on a phone app with cute graphics.Face it, cash is dying out. It is dirty and unhygienic — a report out this week said it is a breeding ground for bugs.There is even a version of Monopoly with debit cards instead of notes. And last month we told you of the  century The Boot pub in Freston, Suffolk, the first boozer in the country to go cashless.This looming death has been around for a while. In August, the Bank of England said it was considering phasing out p and p coins. And ATMs are closing at a rate of  a month.Just  per cent of payments are cash, down from  per cent in . And those payments only account for three per cent in terms of the value of how much is spent.Paying on card has been on the rise ever since Barclaycard launched in , but cards too face being eclipsed by payments on mobile phones. Either way, both mean we need cash less. And that is not a bad thing, right Getting rid of cash would hit criminals and tax evaders hard as they do business in cash to make it harder for authorities to track the movement of money.Businesses would rejoice because they would not have to pay security guards to transport money and would not have to spend ages counting and bagging it.Some also reckon it is easier to keep a tab on finances when spending on cards or apps. You might forget buying that extra round at closing time in the pub, but your phone will always remember. And of course, you get consumer protection when using a credit card, along with reward points or cashback offers.Credit card firms make their money not just from interest payments but from taking a small fee for each transaction — so they offer us incentives to choose their cards. Use an Air Miles card and before long you could have a free flight to Paris or New York.More than a quarter of clothes in the UK are bought online — and you can’t use cash over the internet. As we move even more to buying online and via smartphone apps, cash will be needed less and less. Whether cash dies out in five years or  or  just depends on technology.But many are in no rush to see the back of it — and not just because of nostalgia for their old piggy banks. One consideration is: Can we entirely trust the banks to look after our money  Fraud is soaring as criminals take advantage of security issues around online banking. Banks blame customers but critics say banks need to take responsibility.We have featured victim after victim on The Sun Money columns, and they all say bank staff have turned their backs on them. There are millions of others who need cash simply because they rely on it to pay for things day to day. And it is the less well off or elderly who rely on it the most.Consumer magazine Which  — which has been campaigning against the loss of banks and ATMs — has produced research showing poorer families and older folk are hardest hit.Gareth Shaw of Which  said: “ATM and branch closures are threatening to leave behind the millions who still rely on cash. Our research highlights lower-income families and older generations will be among the worst hit.”In June, services from Visa, one of the three main card providers along with Mastercard and American Express, went down with technical issues — highlighting the risk of being solely reliable on cards and phones. “When the trolley came around on the train and the card payment wasn’t working, the only people who could eat were those with cash,” one banker explained.And what about hospitality workers  The Government has said all tips, evenon cards, must go to staff — but we all know some unscrupulous bosses will not do that. Like many, I prefer to give my tips in cash so I know the waiter or waitress gets it all.Charity collectors often have card machines now but collections for most churches, schools and small local good causes still rely on tins and the rattle of coins.Cash may well be dying out, but I still make sure I always keep some coins in my pocket just in case. And I have older relatives who still feel most comfortable with coins and notes.So until we have a population where everyone feels happy when using a card or phone, I will be rooting against a completely cashless Britain.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: emmanuel macron stop brexit second eu referendum
story: The Prime Minister warned the rest of her ministers that the French hardline boss is holding out hope that another referendum could be on the cards.And it might push EU leaders into giving us a bad dealthey think they can force another vote where Britain opts to stay in the bloc, The Times reported.The French President is pushing for the EU to pursue a hardline approach with Mrs May in Brexit talks - and is said to be among several members who want to punish us for leaving.He told other leaders that Britains current Chequers deal wouldnt stand in the EU - and threatened to block another special summit to finalise a deal unless the PM made more concessions.The French president has warned that a trade deal with Britain cant come at the expense of the EUs integrity.But meddling Mr Macron launched an extraordinary attack on the leaders of the leave campaign during the referendum after the Salzburg summit.He branded Brexiteers as liars just hours after the EU tore apart Mrs Mays Brexit plans.And he said last month that Britain should for sure reverse Brexit because voters didnt realise how complex it would be.He denied meddling with British politics but said he would welcome the UK ing to the EU.However, Mr Macron has been using Brexit to his advantage - reportedly flying over top CEOs on private jets over to France for meetings.He has made no secret of his desire to nick British jobs after we leave, especially in the financial services sector which London competes fiercely with Paris for.Today EU boss Donald Tusk hit out at Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunts insulting comments comparing the EU to the Soviet Union over Brexit.But he also piled pressure on Mrs May to ditch her hated Chequers plans and go for a Canada-style free trade agreement instead.

title: jeremy corbyn is so thick putin
story: Vladimir Putin heads what is now, for all intents and purposes, a rogue state.The former KGB man treats international law as just rules to be broken.And in all of this, he is aided by useful idiots here in the UK.It’s an old-school Soviet tactic. Find a gullible public figure who will cheerlead for the Russian regime while spreading doubt and misinformation.But even in his wildest dreams, the former KGB man never would have thought he’d have the Leader of the Opposition parroting his propaganda.We can never forget that Jeremy Corbyn’s first response to the Salisbury attacks was to suggest shipping samples to the Russians.Here is a man who wants to be Prime Minister, yet is so blindingly thick that he thinks we should have given Vlad the chance to mark his own homework.The diligent work of the Anglo-Dutch intelligence operation to reveal further evidence of Moscow’s criminality must be applauded. title: luke and ryan hart
story: On July  , their dad Lance, , ate his last supper - a ready meal paella - picked up his shotgun and drove to the local leisure centre, where he murdered his we Claire and daughter Charlotte in cold blood.With a rambling -page note in hand, in which he attempted to justy the slaughter of his family - “I had to do this… Revenge is a dish best served cold” - he then shot himself.It came as a bloody end to a campaign of abuse that lasted years, with Lance taking every chance he could to inflict emotional wounds on his family.His relentless bullying had become so bad that Luke and Ryan, now  and , had helped their -year-old sister and mum to escape from the family home, in Spalding, Lincolnshire, just days before the killings.And now the brothers - who have recently written a book about their ordeal - know the terrying truth: their evil father had been planning to butcher his entire family all along.In his murder note, Lance, a builders merchant, claimed he “had to” kill Claire because she and Charlotte had decided to leave him.But police found drafts of it on his laptop from long before they’d left the family home - a desperate move they had been forced to make five days earlier, fearing for their safety.“We want to get across that our dad didn’t kill because of a reaction to something. It wasn’t emotional. It was planned,” Ryan tells The Sun.“He was writing drafts of his murder note at least a month before we decided to move out.“So we were sitting there with him as he was typing up a note about killing us.“I think he’d always had it in the back of his mind that he would kill us when we were no longer useful to him.”“He used to march around the house at night, he says. And that’s exactly what witnesses said he did before he shot himself. So at home he was clearly trying to work himself up.”Before the day of the murder, Lance didnt physically attack his family, but he did coercively control them - taking charge of every aspect of their lives.However, it was only after they lost their mum and sister that the brothers discovered this kind of non-violent domestic abuse is more likely to turn deadly than violent domestic abuse.“We thought he’d start hitting us and we’d know this is getting lethal,” says Luke.But that never happened.The brothers childhood was spent in the Cambridgeshire countryside, living under their fathers bizarre and oppressive tyranny.“We were poor. We grew our own food. We were almost like Russian peasants,” said Luke.Lance didn’t have any friends, except on forums online, and he didn’t want Claire to have any either.But she was naturally friendly and managed to make connections in the community.Unhappy that his we was defying his control, Lance moved his family to a small village outside Spalding in Lincolnshire so fast that nobody knew where they had gone, and his behaviour escalated.Claire started working in Morrisons but he made her hand over her wages, rationing them back to her.Meanwhile she’d look after the children and complete lists of chores he’d leave round the house for her, including filling up his car - that only he drove.The one time she had a friend around he sat in the neighbouring room listening.“If he could keep her busy she had no time to see other people or build a le,” says Luke.“It was part of his isolation strategy.”Ryan remembers arbitrary rules becoming a normal aspect of their lives.“We got the bus back from school, ing at . nearly on the dot every day. Dinner was ready at ..If we were late, which we always would be, we’d be shouted at.“He wanted to find ways to attack us - whether they were legitimate or not.”The brothers realise now that their father saw them as competition.“He only ever got involved in our lives to try to hinder us,” says Ryan. “He liked humiliating us.”So the boys learned to never express an opinion or question anything.They didn’t make friends - too scared for them to come around and face Lance - and spent all their time silently doing homework.“Our le was a prison. We never had an identity,” says Luke.They were also followed around the home by their dad.“In winter we didn’t have the heating on except in the living room to force everyone in there, says Ryan.“If we moved he would sneak around and follow us, adds Luke.He would break into the toilet sometimes just to keep an eye on us.”He’d even secretly stalk Claire to her work at Morrisons, spying on her to see who she was talking to.But bright Luke and Ryan figuredthey could ace their exams it would lead to earning good salaries: a means of escape for their mum and Charlotte.After getting straight A*s, Luke went to Warwick University, and Ryan Durham, and they worked as engineers after graduating.“Going to uni was the first time ever I’d been able to relax. I realised people were actually quite nice, says Ryan. “That’s when I started to think we could live a better le.”Five days before the murders, in a terrying two-hour window before their dad came back from work for his lunch, Luke and Ryan moved Claire out of the family home into a house theyd found.“We were on edge. We knew we had to get out by  and we just made it,” says Ryan.Claire left Lance lunch and a note saying she’d left and would email him later.They’d planned to meet on Monday to exchange documents so she wasn’t surprised to see him the car park of the leisure centre - but she didnt expect him to be holding a gun.“When he realised his control had gone that’s when he decided to kill us all,” says Luke.The brothers were both away when it happened, but remember the sickening sense of dread they felt when they turned on the news.They believe the only reason he didnt kill them too was because they were away, and Luke adds that he is unsure his dad ever loved them.“I think it’s impossible to love when you hate,” he says.“And I think he always wanted to die. I think really violent men inherently become very reckless and self-destructive.”In the months after the murders, Luke started writing to process his feelings, and has now published a book, Operation Lighthouse.Named after the police’s name for the case, the book is a rallying cry for society to act on domestic abuse - and they hope it will help people recognise the signs of coercive control.However, the brothers say the emphasis shouldn’t be on the woman escaping because this can be near-impossible.“The abuser takes financial resources away, isolates you from friends and family, takes your work away, destroys your esteem and then you have nothing, explains Luke.So how do you escape  You have literally nothing. That’s the problem.Their mum and sister couldnt have been more dferent to Lance.Claire,  when she was killed, cared about other people so deeply that she had learned sign language to speak to one customer who she saw for just a few minutes a week.Charlotte, meanwhile, used to spend her time volunteering with the elderly and disabled.“They were angels and our father was evil,” says Luke.A lot of families are plagued by these behaviours eventhey’re not lethal, he adds. They still ruin people’s lives.“So we’re trying to start a conversation and make as much noise as we can.”Operation Lighthouse: Reflections on our Familys Devastating Story of Coercive Control and Domestic Homicide is out now, independently published, Amazon £..Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: infrared image hidden secret house
story: But a further investigation by an expert revealed a sweet surprise for the American owners of this brick property.David Glover aka The Bartlett Bee Whisperer had to hack into the home’s exterior in Germantown, Tennessee, to show exactly what was lurking behind the solid brick wall.A huge honeycomb – complete with thousands of honey bees – was taking up a decent chunk of the wall cavity in one of Glover’s toughest jobs.In a Facebook post, which has been shared more than , times, he admitted: “Every once in a while I get a call that makes me cringe.“Sometimes the bees are way up high, and sometimes it’s bricks.“I prefer to be minimally invasive when removing honey bees from buildings. I don’t like taking out bricks.“Will the mortar chip out, or will the bricks crumble  Will the [honey] combs be usable once the bricks are out of the way  As much as I dreaded removing the bricks the final view of the hive was AWESOME!“The homeowner was more than pleased that we were able to remove and relocate the bees and their hive.”Incredible images and video footage helped the beekeeper identy where the bees may be living before proving it with an infrared picture and then starting to remove the bricks.As he removed more bricks he began to uncover a huge honeycomb beneath a window, which remained intact.After safely removing it, Glover pointed out the stain left behind by thousands of tiny bee feet walking on the white surface.He explained to Bored Panda: “Step-by-step the area of the home is opened, and all combs removed. Brood combs are rubber banded into hive frames and honey goes into a bucket .“If the homeowner is willing to eat a piece of comb with me, it’s probably never been sprayed. The bees who do not follow the combs into the new hive box are vacuumed into a two-stage vacuum. They are added back to the new hive once they are set up in their new yard.After the Bee Whisperer rescues bees, he uses them to repopulate empty hive boxes for local beekeepers who have suffered colony losses.He added: “No one is aware of the size of their honey bee hive. They are all surprised because they are expecting something the size of a wasp nest or hornet’s nest.“The infrared gives them the first clue, but that’s only the brood combs of the hive.The babies are incubated at . degrees Celsius. Any honey combs in the hive are cooler and usually don’t show on the IR.”

title: asshat douchebaggery and fam among 1400 new phrases added to oxford dictionary sparking controversy
story: Other controversial additions, which were announced today, include douchebaggery, asshat, updation and Pooh-sticks.A surprising number of slang words have also made it into the dictionary - most notably the phrase bump and grind, which OED describes as a dancers erotic gyration of the hips.Among the slang words set to appear on the pages of the dictionary is butters, an adjective commonly used to describe someone or something as ugly.Another on the list is bum-suck, which is a colloquialism for a brown nose or suck up. Crip-walk - a dance invented by the US-based Crip gang in the s - has also been added.And the word ducket - slang for money - is now included in the official list of words used in the English language.By far the most controversial new entry is the word fam, short for family.It was first seen as graphic abbreviation in the th century but only started to be used as slang in the s in the US hip hop scene.OEDs head of US dictionaries Katherine Connor Martin said it has now been adopted in the UK, especially in London.She said: The original meaning of family was soon extended to people who were not ones actual relatives, but rather close friends or fellow members of a particular group, and it became common as a form of direct address , either to a single person or to many.But the changes have not gone unnoticed by Brits, who have taken to social media to challenge OED.One user tweeted: Fam  Are you kidding me  Another gobsmacked user wrote: Fam is becoming a word. Fam is becoming and actual word.Others took issue with the word updation. Please get rid of updation, one man requested.Updation is defined as the action or act of updating something. Ms Martin said it was a nominalisation of the verb update.

title: queen moving buckingham palace refurbishment private rooms
story: Britains longest reigning monarch will have to switch suites as part of a refit of the building to prevent a catastrophic disaster such as a fire or a flood, a senior royal official said today.Three thousand items including  paintings,  chandeliers and  mirrors will be removed before wiring and pipes are replaced.The works, which started in spring last year, have led to , metres of dangerous vulcanised rubber cabling being ripped out in a bid to ward off a potentially catastrophic failure.Towards the end of the project, the -year-old monarch and her husband Prince Philip, , will have to move out of their apartments in the palaces north wing for about two years when work starts there in .The queen is immensely pragmatic and she wants to stay in the palace, the official told reporters. She said let me know where you would like me to go.The Prince of Wales is said to be fully engaged with the project, while the Duke of Edinburgh is also keeping a close eye on developments.Mr Johnstone-Burt said: We all take the responsibility that comes with using public funds to do all this work on such a national icon like Buckingham Palace extremely seriously indeed.... on time, within budget and to the required specication.Work is now underway to empty the famous East Wing, the public facade of the building which includes the balcony on which the royal family appears on special occasions.Next week, a compound for  contractors will be erected on the forecourt to one side of the building but the palace will remain fully open for state visits and other regular events.I am absolutely convinced that by making this investment in the palace now, we will... avert a much more costly and potentially catastrophic failure of the building in the years to come, he said.The emptying of the East Wing will mean three of the queens four children - Princess Anne, Prince Andrew and Prince Edward - moving their offices. Heir-to-the-throne Prince Charles will be unaffected as his London home is at nearby Clarence House.Tim Knox, Director of the Royal Collection, said some of these items would go on public display at other palaces while  objects wouldto the Royal Pavilion in Brighton, George IVs bizarre seaside home on the south coast of England from where they were moved in  when that residence was sold.Buckingham Palace was built in  as a large private home and was only acquired by the monarch, King George III, in .The East Wing was part of an extension built in the reign of Queen Victoria. The front facade was refaced in  in harder-wearing Portland stone when George V - Elizabeths grandfather - was on the throne.

title: unilever shareholders bared their teeth and won
story: There were other criticisms, too. Unilever got the fright of its le when, in February last year, US food giant Kraft Heinz approached it about a bn takeover. This restructuring was seen as a way for the company, which has a Dutch chairman and chief executive, to avoid such incidents in future because the Netherlands has tougher takeover laws than the City. Mark Rutte, the Dutch prime minister and a former Unilever employee, did his bit to smooth the way by promising to abolish a tax on idends that made holding the shares in the UK more attractive than in the Netherlands.One by one, the big battalions of City fund managers, many of whom prefer to speak on an anonymous basis to the financial press, broke cover to say what a dreadful idea this was: Colombia Threadneedle, Lindsell Train, Schroders, Aviva Investors, MG and Royal London all publicly stated their opposition. With Unilever needing the backing of % of UK investors to go ahead with the reorganisation, it was starting to look like a close-run thing.Yet that was not the only dficulty that emerged for the consumer goods giant.The influential Financial Times columnist Neil Collins, the most vocal critic of the move from the start, spotted in the small print of the particulars sent to investors that Unilever also required a simple majority of shareholders taking part in the vote for the motion to be passed. story: NewsBrett Kavanaugh: Senator Susan Collins says #MeToo matters - then votes YES to Supreme Court nomineeRepublican Susan Collins, a key swing vote, sparked a furious backlash by voting to advance judge Kavanaughs confirmationShareByNatalie EvansAmber Hicks:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video kavanaugh-track-supreme-court-after-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDonald Trumps Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh was one step closer to being confirmed last night after key senators voted in his favour. Two crucial senators said that the sexual misconduct accusations against the judge would not prevent them from voting to confirm him. Republican Susan Collins and Democrat Joe Manchin, both seen as swing votes, said they would support Kavanaugh, after weeks of debate about sexual violence and the nominees character and temperament that gripped the nation. Sen. Collins, from Maine, sparked a furious backlash which saw more than million raised to challenge her in the  election within hours of her vote. She addressed Dr. Christine Blasey Ford and last weeks Senate hearing regarding the assault allegations brought against Kavanaugh.  She told the Senate committe: I found her testimony to be sincere, painful and compelling. I believe that she is a survivor of a sexual assault and that this trauma has upended her le. Nevertheless, the four witnesses she named could not corroborate any of the events.  Collins also mentioned the #MeToo movement, brought about a year ago following accusations against Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein. She said: The #MeToo Movement is real. It matters. It is needed, and it is long overdue.  A sharply partisan battle over the nomination became an intense personal and political drama when university professor Ford accused Kavanaugh of sexually assaulting her when they were high school students in Maryland in . Collins, in remarks on the Senate floor explaining her decision to back Kavanaugh, said Fords accusations against him fail to meet the more-likely-than-not standard.  As protesters in a Capitol Hill hallway shouted, Shame! Shame! Shame!, Manchin told reporters an FBI investigation, which did not find corroborating evidence of Fords accusations, was thorough. “I believe Dr. Ford. Something happened to Dr. Ford. I don’t believe the facts show that it was Brett Kavanaugh, but I believe something happened,” Manchin said.  Earlier on Friday afternoon in the US, the Senate voted - in favour of his nomination. The final vote on whether the -year-old will get a lelong seat in the highest court in the US is set to be announced later today.  President Donald Trump tweeted: Very proud of the U.S. Senate for voting “YES” to advance the nomination of Judge Brett Kavanaugh! Kavanaugh, who was nominated for the role by President Trump, has denied the sexual assault allegations during a dramatic marathon hearing in front of a Senate committee. His fate might still be in the hands of a few key senators in a chamber where Republicans hold only a razor-thin majority. Confirmation would hand President Trump a clear victory and tip the balance on the court to a - majority in favour of conservatives in possible legal battles ahead over contentious issues such as abortion rights and immigration. On Thursday evening, actresses Emily Ratajkowski and Amy Schumer were arrested while protesting against Kavanaughs nomination. The stars, along with more than  others, were detained by police as they took to the streets in Washington DC. Ratajkowski shared a photograph of herself in front of the US Capitol brandishing a sign reading Respect female existence or expect our resistance. She wrote on Twitter: I was arrested protesting the Supreme Court nomination of Brett Kavanaugh, a man who has been accused by multiple women of sexual assault. Men who hurt women can no longer be placed in positions of power.  Schumer is also a vocal supporter against controversial Kavanaugh being appointed to the highest court in the land when the vote is carried out this weekend. She previously wrote on Twitter: We BelieveSurvivors and refuse to accept Brett Kavanaugh as our next Supreme Court Justice.” She encouraged others to join protests across America. Last week, the Senate Judiciary Committee heard emotional testimony from Professor Christine Blasey Ford, who has accused Kavanaugh of sexually assaulting her when they were teenagers.  University professor Dr Ford fought back tears before the Senate Judiciary committee as she said Kavanaugh assaulted her at a High School party when she was  and he . I believed he was going to rape me, she declared. She said she tried to yell for help but Kavanaugh put his hand over her mouth. He and a friend of his were drunkenly laughing during the attack, she added.  Dr Ford said she could not remember the location or exact date of the incident  years ago, but said she was  per cent sure it was Kavanaugh who assaulted her. Two other women, Deborah Ramirez and Julie Swetnick, have accused conservative Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct in the s. But in an angry, extraordinary statement at the committee, Kavanaugh blasted Democratic senators and accused opponents of a calculated and orchestrated political hit.  Calling himself a victim of grotesque and obvious character assassination, Kavanaugh said he unequivocally and categorically denied Fords allegation. I swear today, under oath, before the Senate and the nation, before my family and God, I am innocent of this charge, he said. The protest in the US capital city last night took place after senators were given a report by the FBI which investigated the allegations made against Kavanagh and which Republicans have said proves there was no wrongdoing. Last night Kavanaugh also took the highly unusual step for a judge of penning a Wall Street Journal opinion piece denying the claims against him.

title: eu chief jean claude juncker
story: NewsEU chief Jean-Claude Juncker blasts warring Tories for leaving him to pick up the pieces of BrexitThe EU Commission President complained that Brussels was being left to “arrange the pieces” of the split at the top of GovernmentShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsTheresa May’s warring Cabinet are to blame for Brexit isions, Jean-Claude Juncker claimed "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May’s warring Cabinet are to blame for Brexit isions, Jean-Claude Juncker claimed today. The EU Commission President complained that Brussels was being left to “arrange the pieces” of the split at the top of Government.But EU sources suggested a Brexit deal was “very close” as the clock counts down to the deadline.Mr Juncker told Austria’s parliament: “Negotiations are not easy because we also have to be critical that we receive dferent signals from London. “There is a polyphonic chorus at the level of the British Cabinet and we try to arrange the pieces ... so that they become a melody.” His comments will fuel tensions in the run-up to this month’s crunch showdown where EU leaders will bid to thrash out a UK exit plan.  Bloc chiefs hope to strike a deal in Brussels in less than two weeks, before rubber-stamping the pact at a one-off meeting in November. Mr Juncker hoped October’s European Council summit would make “enough progress” that “we can see it through in November”. No deal would be “devastating”, he added. Mrs May was under mounting pressure tonight to bring forward plans to break the deadlock over the Northern Ireland border. Dublin’s Europe Minister Helen McEntee was confident a deal could be struck, but warned negotiations were reaching a “critical point”. Mrs May rejected the EU’s proposal for a “backstop” to prevent a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic after Brexit.

title: trust tories make brexhibition shambolic
story: NewsopinionTrust the Tories to make a Brexhibition of their shambolic selves, says Brian ReadeWhich sight or sound at the Tory conference most made you questionyou belonged to the same species as the on-loan collection from the Natural History Museum ShareCommentsByBrian Reade:,  OCT NewsopinionVile Tory students show their true blue colours"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIts the toughest ask not just of this year but any year. Which sight or sound at the Tory conference most made you questionyou belonged to the same species as the on-loan collection from the Natural History Museum Was it the Prime Minister dancing on stage , hoping we’d view her not as the priggish s vicar’s daughter she is but as a free-loving wild child of the s  Yet making us think only of the time our primary school headmistress had a stroke at assembly.How about the Home Secretary sending ripples through underwear with the promise of a test to ensure foreigners understand British culture, despite sitting alongside a Northern Ireland Secretary who didn’t know that in Belfast “people who are nationalists don’t vote for unionist parties”.Could it have been Jacob Rees-Mogg , that love child of Beano character Walter The Softy and ventriloquist dummy Lord Charles, assuring us a hard Brexit would be a success “because it’s a Conservative thing to be doing” What, like the Bedroom Tax and plans to scrape the homeless from Windsor’s streets with JCB diggers before the last royal wedding Or the tired faux-shambolic act Boris Johnson puts on which has worn thinner than the truth on his CV  Well, I’m giving the prize to this year’s Big Idea: A festival to showcase “what makes our country great” which will be known as The Great Brexhibition of . The great news is that the paltry poundmillion set aside for it should suffice. If we hold it near Dover we won’t need security fences as we can ask the -mile queue of lorries to form a circle. Plus, the last Nissan truck to roll off the production line should do for the Great Global Trade Hall. Visitors will be welcomed by a glass case containing a huge laughing clown with Lord Farage’s face. There will be food stalls replicating the grub on sale at the  Festival of Britain . We’ll have a Red Arrows flypast to remind us what it was like when there were planes in the sky and Magic Money Trees with IOUs hanging from their rotting branches. To prove we’re open for business with the rest of the world, Rees-Mogg and John Redwood will run a financial advice bureau showing how to relocate your shares offshore – and Lord Lawson will hand out timeshare brochures for his French villa. As a sign of our generosity we’ll hand out free bottles of water but not that rip-off French Evian stuff. This will be locally collected tears of the poor. A plentul post-Brexit resource. What will be vital is an opening ceremony like Danny Boyle’s at the  Olympics. One that pumps up the feelgood factor.

title: what happens next brexit theresa
story: NewsWhat happens next with Brexit: Is Theresa Mays Chequers plan dead  Can a deal with the EU be reached and will there be another general election The Brexit negotiations reach their endgame in the next few weeks. This is your guide to what could happen nextShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email We are nearing the moment of truth. In the next few weeks the Brexit negotiations will reach their final stage.Can Theresa May strike a deal  And,so, what happens then The Prime Minister still has to reach a compromise with Brussels on her unloved Chequers plan .Then she has to present the deal to Parliament for MPs’ approval. The stakes could not be higher. Hundreds of thousands of jobs, our national security and economic well-being depend on what happens. Any  step by the Prime Minister and it could spell the end of her time in office. Here’s your guide to a crucial few weeks: What is the next stage   Britain and the EU will resume the Brexit negotiations next week after the stalemate at Salzburg.At the Austrian summit Mrs May’s Chequers plan was bluntly rejected as unworkable.The EU said it did not resolve the Irish border issue and her trade proposals gave Britain access to EU markets without having to abide by the rules on free movement of goods, people and services. Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab is expected to travel to Brussels on Monday to try to break the deadlock. On Wednesday  the President of the EU Jean-Claude Juncker is scheduled to make a declaration on the future trading relationship with the UK. Many believe he will offer the UK a Canada +++with a carve out on Northern Ireland. When will a decision be made   Mrs May will join EU leaders on Wednesday  for a working dinner on Brexit, migration and foreign policy. The following day will be the moment of truth. This is when we will discoverboth sides have found a way to resolve their dferences and have the basis for a potential agreement. If there a deal is in the offing then there will be another summit, pencilled in for November , to sign it off. How could the deadlock be broken   The simple answer is through a large amount of fudge and kicking the contentious issues into the long grass.Theresa May could agree to stick to EU rules on trade and goods to allow the UK to stay in a customs union after the transition period ends in .This would give us more time to bring in the technology needed to allow for frictionless trade across borders. But this would limit our ability to strike independent trade deals - the main prize in the eyes of the Brexiteers of our leaving. To resolve the Irish border question Britain could agree for Northern Ireland to have dferent regulations from the rest of the UK with the checks on goods taking place away from ports, borders and airports.This will require the agreement of the DUP which has been adamant there can be no border in the Irish Sea. Theresa May is expected to presents her plans to Parliament at the end of November or early December. MPs have been offered a meaningful vote on the final deal. What happens depends on who is best at counting. Labour has signalled it would vote down any deal unless it meets all six of its demands.The question for Jeremy Corbyn is what happensMrs May brings back a package which is within a whisker of passing his party’s six tests.The ultimate prize for the Labour leader is for Parliament to vote down Mrs May’s deal paving the way for a general election. But Mr Corbyn has to weigh up the cost of being seen to block what voters may regard as a sensible deal. If Labour does vote against the agreement the Prime Minister will have to rely on a handful of Labour Brexiteers to get it over the line.But they could be outweighed by the diehard Tory Brexiteers who have vowed to block Chequers including Jacob Rees-Mogg , Boris Johnson and Owen Paterson.There is also a risk that one or two Tory remainer MPs may side with Labour. Allies of Mrs May are still confident she can get a deal through Parliament. They believe that when forced to make a decision Tory Brexiteers would rather swallow the Prime Minister’s offering which they can unpick later than risk losing the prize of Brexit altogether. Tory remainers could also drop their objections rather than unleash the chaos which could lead to Jeremy Corbyn coming to power. What we do know is that when the vote comes the numbers will be nail-bitingly tight. What happensthe deal is voted down by Parliament   The short answer is nobody knows. Theresa May would be under immense pressure to resign. MPs would have to conjour up a motion that called on the Prime Minister to go back to the negotiating table.With time running out we would also have to ask for an extension of Article  which set the timetable for our departure.Extending Article  requires the unanimous approval of all  other EU states. They are likely to agree rather than allow the UK to crash out without a deal but we don’t know what price,any, they will demand for such a favour. The EU would have us over a barrel: the options would be the economically ruinous crashing out with no deal or bowing to Brussels in order to get an extension. Could we have another election or a second referendum

title: boy 13 lost legs seven
story: NewsBoy, , lost legs and seven fingers after climbing on train wagon near , volt overhead cablesA company has now been found guilty of a safety breach after the schoolboy was set on fire during the horric incident at a Tyne Yard railway depot in GatesheadShareByBy Rob KennedyKelly-Ann Mills:,  OCT NewsThe boy caught on fire at the rail yard "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA -year-old boy had both legs and seven fingers amputated after climbing on top of a train wagon near ,-volt overhead cables. The boy and three friends had been able to easily gain access to a Tyne Yard railway depot, in Gateshead, which was a common haunt for youngsters. A company has now been found guilty of a safety breach after the schoolboy was set on fire and lost his legs and seven fingers following a rail yard electrocution. A jury found freight operator DB Cargo guilty of failing to protect people from risk, Chronicle Live reports.  A disused signal box known as the “haunted house” was a popular attraction to children at the site, near Birtley, and prosecutors said inadequate measures were in place to keep people off the premises. When two lads began climbing up a wagon, one of them got too close to the live overhead wire and suffered catastrophic injuries. During the trial at Newcastle Crown Court, prosecutor Gordon Menzies said the railway yard was a potentially hazardous area by nature but added: “It was made much more dangerous by the fact that in this yard, on the defendant’s land which it leased from Network Rail, there was a signal box which had not been used since . “It had a reputation among local children and was known as the haunted house. It was something of a lure to not just young children but older children as well.  “The prosecution say the dangers those children were exposed to arise because of the inadequacies of the defendant’s arrangements for keeping that site secure. “It was a hazardous area and was left insecure.” The court heard access to the yard, which is off the East Coast Mainline, could be gained by four bridges off Lamesley Road, near Birtley. Two of them had been safely fenced off but the third had a gate which did not lock properly, while a fourth did not have any gate to prevent pedestrian access, Mr Menzies said. On Saturday June  , two boys and two girls aged between  and , who cannot be named for legal reasons, went to the yard to go to the signal yard. DB Cargo had denied failing to ensure non-employees, including the four children, were not exposed to risk. Mr Menzies told jurors: “There was not a single fence or credible obstacle to prevent them getting to the haunted house and being exposed to the risks that were involved.Mums terror of dragging her children out of bed after home was set on fire in arson attack“There was no security patrol present, there weren’t even any warning signs on the bridge to provide even that minimal level of deterrent. “The prosecution say this was an obvious trespassing route.” After spending time in the signal box, the children began to explore the yard and played on large piles of rubble. The two boys started to climb up a railway wagon in the sidings and one reached the top but suffered an electric shock after getting too close to the overhead cables. It is not necessary to even touch them in order to get an electric shock, jurors heard. His -year-old friend behind him also suffered an electric shock and was thrown to the ground but escaped with minor injuries. Mr Menzies said: “The children described a loud bang andwas thrown to the ground. “ was set on fire and fell to the ground. “He suffered le-changing injuries, including the amputation of both of his legs, one above he knee, one below, and all the fingers and thumb on his right hand, and on his left hand two fingers and part of his left hand itself.”  Prosecutors said DB Cargo did not do enough to ensure people were not exposed to risk. One of the youngsters said for a time she would go there every day and prosecutors say the signal box was a “den”, which the company denies. DB Cargo had arranged security patrols of the signal box but only at night on weekdays, the court heard. It also put up warning signs but pictures showed these had been ripped off. Its own risk assessments showed it was a high risk environment, the court heard. Referring to the children going to the sidings, Mr Menzies said: “There was nothing to stop them, no security guards, none of the staff stopped them, there’s no CCTV in that area. “They were able to roam about half a mile from where they entered the site.”

story: NewsWalkers launching UKs first recycling scheme for crisp packets - weeks after people were posting them backFrom December, customers can either drop off their packets at collection points or post them for free for recyclingShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  OCT NewsThe new scheme is set to be up and running from December "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWalkers is launching the UK’s first recycling scheme for crisp packets - weeks after being bombarded with empty packets in the post. Royal Mail begged environmental campaigners last month to stop sending bags back to the PepsiCo brand, which owns Walkers, as a form of protest because they arent yet recyclable. Now Walkers has announced the new scheme which is set to be up and running from December. Customers will be encouraged to either drop off their packets at collection points or alternatively post them for free directly to TerraCycle for recycling.  Once the packets have been collected they will be cleaned, shredded and turned into small plastic pellets which will then be converted into useful plastic items, such as benches and fence posts. Under the scheme, developed in partnership with the recycling company TerraCycle, all crisp packets will be accepted. Full details of exactly how it will work and locations of the nationwide collection points will be announced nearer the time. Geraint Ashcroft, whose petition against the Leicester-based crisp maker has been signed by more than , people, said the announcement was really exciting. I hope other snack companies get on board, he said.  This is a great first step and makes all the work thats gone into the petition worthwhile. Walkers’ long-term ambition is to make all of its packaging  per cent recyclable, compostable or biodegradable by . It is focusing signicant resource on developing the technology and infrastructure to make this happen. Ian Ellington, General Manager of PepsiCo UK said: “We share people’s concerns about the amount of plastic in our environment and are working on a number of both short and long-term solutions to reduce the impact of our packaging. Our new Walkers recycling initiative starts to tackle this issue right now by repurposing used crisp packets to create everyday items such as plant pots and benches. We hope people will embrace this idea and join us in ensuring crisp packets are recycled.
