They knocked on the door which was partially opened by a woman who looked them up and down before they went in. They were initially turned away by staff because the club only admits patrons who wear fetish or bondage gear.  At first we nearly didnt get in because we were wearing normal clothes, he said. But we had the idea of taking our tops off and the guys at the door let us straight in. The man says he couldnt believe his eyes when he stepped through the doors. They were confronted by a small group of clubgoers wearing a iety of outlandish leather clothing. As soon as I got in, the first thing I saw was an overweight middle-aged man being led by young women across the nightclub, he said. We sat down on a sofa where we were given body paint to use all over our body. While we were sitting down a man in a gimp mask approached us. He put his hands down my friends pants, which he wasnt too happy about.

title: thai caveman beds dozens attractive
story: NewsThai Caveman beds dozens of attractive female backpackers on island and boasts of exploitsChatupoom Losiri, , has shared images of women sleeping naked in his cave in the Full Moon Party island of Koh PhanganShareCommentsByDave Burke:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video meet-the-cave-man-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA self-proclaimed caveman has boasted online about his years spent bedding dozens of young attractive backpackers he seduced on a Thai island. Lothario Chatupoom Losiri posted pictures of several young woman sleeping naked on his bed on Facebook , claiming they had spent the night together. The -year-old also claimed to have bedded a young Russian woman he met outside a grocery store. But furious locals have voiced their fury at his antics, calling for him to be evicted and prompting police to search his home in the Full Moon Party island of Koh Phangan. Despite claims that he lacked decency after his online bragging, no evidence of any wrongdoing was uncovered in the search. Chatupoom calls himself the Thai Caveman - a persona he uses to pick up women.  After posting a picture of a group naked women sleeping, he wrote that he was very tired from the previous evening but still woke up to drink coffee and meditate while they slept. The cavemans antics sparked outrage from locals who accused him of showing a lack of decency after dozens more images emerged of women he had taken back to his cave. Police arrived at the cave, a former tin mine, yesterday and searched for anything suspicious but found nothing. They admitted that Chatupoom had not broken the law but said they would monitor the situation.  Koh Phangan Sherf Kairik Kraisong said: Officials on Koh Phangan have investigated the situation and performed a background check on the person, who was originally domiciled in Bangkok. He graduated with a degree from Silpakorn University. Koh Phangan district has made an inquiry to the landowner whether he will continue to let Mr Chatupoom live in the area or ask him to leave. Now there are no complaints. If there is a complaint, the officers can take legal action. This situation is precarious and risky, so I sent the staff to check and talk with Mr Chatupoom. Speaking to reporters, Chatupoom denied that he had done anything wrong and said that all of the women who visited his cave were there of their own choice.  He said: I came to Koh Phangan to play music but shortly after the band broke up. Now I earn a living by painting art and selling it to tourists. The women who sleep here, there is no compulsion in any way. None of the women are forced to do anything, and sometimes we dont have sex. Sometimes we just hug until morning. They are all happy and Im happy, too.

title: tourist gets red dragon massage
story: NewsTourist gets red dragon massage but is shocked to discover what that really meansMatthew and Candise Raison, from Australia, were on holiday in Bali when they decided to treat themselves to a massage but he got more than he bargained forShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAustralian tourist Matthew Raison was left with raised red marks on his back after getting a red dragon massage in Bali"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA tourist was left shocked when he opted for what he thought was a relaxing red dragon massage but was left huge red marks across his back. Matthew and Candise Raison, from Australia, were on holiday in Bali along with his sister Tamzin when they decided to get a relaxing massage. They opted for a go jek massage where the masseur comes to you as the ultimate holiday treat. But Matthew didnt know what the masseur meant when he askedhe wanted him to get the red dragon out of him.  Speaking to Daily Mail Australia, Candise said her husband thought the masseur was trying some prayer thing. She told him: I dont know what youre saying but my husband will try anything, go for it! However, they soon found out what the masseur really meant as he started to carve into Matthews back with a coin. The massage is called Gua sha which is an Asian medical practice where the side of a coin is rubbed in parallel stripes on the chest and back. Its often referred to as scraping or coining and is believed to release unhealthy body matter from sore, tired, or injured muscles and stimulate new, oxygenated blood flow.  The red marks ran from the top of his neck all the way down to his tailbone. Despite looking like he had been hurt with the red raised marks covering his back, Matthew and Candise saw the funny side. Its fair to say we were all in tears of laughter, she said. Despite the unsightly appearance, the massage brought Matthew some relief from his chronic back pain. Candise said her husband, who works on power lines, has had a sore back for almost three years.

title: builder whose 150 home plans were refused says 550 folk overwhelmingly from dundee are interested
story: A housebuilder has hit out at councillors in Dundee who turned down its plan to build  homes earlier this year, describing their decision as “baffling”.Kirkwood Homes is appealing against a decision by Dundee’s planning committee to reject its proposal for a new housing development at Linlathen, north of Broughty Ferry in June.Colin Crombie, managing director at Kirkwood Homes, told the Tele he found it hard to understand councillors’ thinking, given that planning officers had recommended the plans be approved.He said: “We had worked closely and very well with Dundee City Council’s planning officers to ensure that this £ million development met their own policies, guidance and aspirations.“Once again, we were left baffled by the decision of councillors to ignore the advice of their officers, as well as the  notes of interest that came overwhelmingly from the Dundee area – interest that demonstrated a clear desire and need for new housing of this type in and around Broughty Ferry.”He said that, because of the support of planning officials and locals the firm “simply had no choice” but to appeal.The Scottish Government is likely to make a decision on the appeal before the end of the year.

title: can roarie be dundees deacon of hope
story: Former Arsenal kid Roarie Deacon’scoincided with Dundee’s first league victory of the season – could he be the piece that’s been missing from their Premiership jigsaw The -year-old, who signed from English National League side Sutton United last summer, has missed the entire start of the season after having ankle surgery.Picking up the injury in the final game of last season, the enigmatic attacker ed for the final six minutes of the club’s first league win of the season – at the seventh time of the asking – at Hamilton and, in the process, set up the second goal.And hiswas hailed by manager Neil McCann.He said: “Roarie Deacon I am really pleased about getting back in because we have suffered some real injury problems of late.“He hadn’t featured at all, he’d only had  minutes of football all season before Saturday but I knew putting him on he could secure the ball because he is so strong.“You can’t get close to Roarie and he turned the boy beautully, then he had the composure.“I have to commend the other boys as well because they were still trying to get into the box at that stage to get the killer goal.”Deacon himself was delighted to be back in action after his y spell out.A process that was extended after an older injury reared its head once more.His debut season was also curtailed by injury with a troublesome thigh problem picked up in December at Hearts keeping him out of action for a big chunk of the middle of the campaign.And, on histo training this season, he hurt the same thigh once more.Deacon said: “I had ankle surgery the first week into pre-season.“I twisted it and damaged ankle ligaments in the game against Partick and through the summer it didn’t heal itself.“The surgeon didn’t want to operate initially but it didn’t heal itself so we made the decision to go under the kne to sort it out.“I was supposed to be back a little earlier than this but on the first session back I re-injured my thigh, a problem I had last season, so I needed a bit of intense rehabilitation on that to get back.“Now, though, I am ready to go and I’m fit.”With goals being a real issue for the side – just four scored in their seven league games and half of them against Accies at the weekend – Deacon’sis a timely boost for the Dark Blues.In fact, he’s only played around six minutes this season but has already had a hand in a quarter of their league goals.Coming into the side struggling for goals and points, though, hasn’t ruffled Deacon in any way.And Dundee fans will be hoping his direct running and ability to go past people is the key that unlocks defences with tough matches against Kilmarnock on Saturday and then Livingston, Hearts and Celtic in the next month.The former Sutton man admits he’s surprised the Dark Blues find themselves bottom of the table as he s to fitness and has backed them to get up the table,they keep doing what they’ve been doing.He added: “I am very surprised, everyone is surprised.“No way we thought we would come in, do well in pre-season, and then come in and after six games not have a point on the board.“However, after Hamilton everyone is positive, you can’t not be because the way we’ve been playing it’s not like we’ve not created chances or played well despite not getting points.“Everyone is buzzing about in training, raring to go and wanting to do well for Dundee.”

title: celebrity chef nick nairn cooks up a treat at dundee cooking demonstration
story: Celebrity chef Nick Nairn cooked up a treat as he delivered an advice-packed cooking demonstration at Abertay University.The -year-old – who was awarded an honorary doctorate by the institution in  – shared top tips with food and drink students on how to deliver cooking demonstrations of their own.Nick said: “To be a doctor of the university, in the university talking to students who’re studying the science of food and cooking, is a real privilege.“Hopefully they’ll all go on to have great careers because there’s so much happening in food at the moment.“It’s really a good time to work in the industry.”Last year Abertay opened new £. million science labs, including the only industry-standard consumer testing lab in any Scottish university.Nick rose to fame when he became the youngest Scottish chef to win a Michelin star in .

title: closed dundee gp practice closes its doors for good
story: A Dundee GP practice has closed its doors to patients for the final time.Fintry Mill Medical Centre shut for good at pm on Friday after efforts to recruit more GPs failed.All services will be transferred to Arthurstone Medical Centre on Arthurstone Terrace.A spokesman for Dundee Health and Social Care Partnership said: “All health boards across Scotland are facing a national shortage of GPs and NHS Tayside is no exception.“Despite continuing efforts, Mill Practice in Dundee, which has premises at Arthurstone Medical Centre and Fintry Mill Medical Centre, has been unsuccessful in recruiting GPs to fill three practice vacancies.“A public engagement exercise was led by Dundee Health and Social Care Partnership in conjunction with Fintry Mill Practice and a report was presented to the meeting of the Integration Joint Board held on August .“In order for the practice to continue to provide the best service for all registered patients, the decision was taken by Mill Practice to permanently close its Fintry Mill branch on Friday October .“All patients registered with Fintry Mill Practice have been notied of the closure date explaining that after this date patients will be seen at the Mill Practice.”Fintry Community Council chairman Ron Neave said the situation was a “shambles”.He added: “This is a devastating situation for the community.“It is going to affect everyone in the community who goes to the practice, including the elderly, disabled and vulnerable.“The practice had only recently taken on patients from the Stobswell Medical Practice which was also forced to close earlier this year.“It’s a complete shambles. It means that people are now going to have to travel much further afield to see a doctor.”

title: council could make bid to turn iconic nightclub flicks into homes
story: Angus Council chiefs may go to auction in a bid to rescue Brechin’s former Flicks nightclub for affordable housing.Once a magnet for nightclubbers from across the country, and a venue which hosted a string of s stars, the property has been branded a blight on the town’s High Street following years of advancing dereliction.It has now emerged the Irish-based developers who own the former cinema have knocked back a council offer to buy the building for an undisclosed sum, but with the prospect of the property being offered at auction the authority has not ruled out making a bid.Originally opened as the -seat Kings cinema in , Flicks rocketed on to the UK’s nightclub scene in the mid-s after a major investment by a trio of local businessmen, attracting clubbers from all over the UK as well as music and television celebrity appearances.It closed almost  years ago after an unsuccessful rebranding and has languished on Scotland’s Buildings at Risk register for many years, becoming a target for vandals and suffering continuing deterioration.

title: dates announced for local christmas events
story: With the countdown on to Christmas, members of Arbroath Ladies Leboat Guild are hard at work on plans for the run-up to the special day.Tickets are on sale for the Big Fish Supper Quiz on October  in the Bell Rock Restaurant.Following the success of the annual RNLI fundraising event last year, the guild is hoping for another good response.Tickets are £ each for teams of four and are available from the RNLI shop, any member of the guild or Mo Morrison on  .The grand Christmas card sale takes place on October -. It will be held in the RNLI shop from am-pm on both days.Shop manager Mary Gerrard has been ensuring there is a good selection of cards and calendars available.The RNLI shop goes into winter hours in November and December, when it will only be open on Saturday and Sundays from -pm.A Christmas craft evening will also be held at the beginning of November in the Royal British Legion Halls. Tickets will be £, with funds going towards the upkeep of the Arbroath leboat, station and crew.Tickets will be available from the guild and the shop, and more information, including the date, will be available nearer the time.

title: dundee man broke into city pub and made menacing remarks to cops
story: Ryan O’Neil, , of Gleneagles Street, avoided a jail term after breaking into a city pub.He admitted breaking into Lochee Sports Club with intention to steal on August .O’Neil also admitted making threats of violence and menacing remarks to officers at police headquarters on Bell Street.Sherf Derek Reekie placed him on a restriction of liberty order between pm-am and  months’ supervision.

title: dundee roads team ready another beast from the east as thousands tonnes salt stockpiled
story: It#s getting cold out there – and the folk responsible for keeping the roads safe as winter rolls in are set to roll out.Dundee Roads Maintenance Partnership and BEAR Scotland’s North East Unit have stockpiled salt to the rafters to grit roads and paths from now until April.Following the mighty Beast from the East, which crippled the country’s road networks in March, the teams say they are now ready for anything winter throws at the region.Mark Flynn, deputy convener of Dundee City Council’s city development committee, said the council has stockpiled thousands of tonnes of salt.“We will have , tonnes of salt ready and waiting at the Marchbanks Depot by next week with the ability to bring in moreit is needed,” he said.“When you think that theof roads we have in the city would stretch from here to Birmingham and the pavements that would take you to beyond Exeter, the crews do a tremendous job clearing and gritting.”The council, through arms- body Tayside Contracts, has up to  staff,  road gritters and  footpath spreaders ready to tackle slippy streets.Eight tractors equipped with gritting carts can be called inthe going gets really tough.Gritters will prioritise main roads, later moving onto side streets and cul-de-sacs.Mr Flynn conceded that, as the cold weather bites, locals could be frustrated at a perceived lack of action where they live.However, with about  miles of roads and  miles of pavements to cover – and £. m spent each year on making them safe – he appeals for patience.He added: “It is obviously not possible to clear them all at the same time, particularly in snow conditions when the gritters and ploughs have to treat the same sections of roads and footways more than once.“So during snowy weather you’ll see the fleet of gritters around the city during the day clearing snow, but they’re also active at other times gritting early in the morning or during the night.”Meanwhile, BEAR Scotland is set to treat the trunk roads around Dundee with its army of curiously-named gritters.The firm’s North East Unit will deploy Plougher O’ Scotland, based at Cunmont Depot in Newbigging, should roads such as the A threaten to ice over.Other gritters being deployed across the North East include Gritty Gritty Bang Bang, Sir Grits-a-lot, Sir Andy Flurry and For Your Ice Only.In all, the unit has  machines at its disposal, including  road spreaders, five footway gritters and two snow-blowers, capable of moving , tonnes of snow an hour.The firm has been carrying out dry runs this week to make sure their equipment is ready.Alasdair Allen, senior operations manager, said: “We have  dedicated, trained and experienced employees ready to deal with winter across the trunk roads that we maintain across the north east of Scotland.“Our teams work exceptionally hard around the clock during what can be very challenging conditions in order to keep trunk roads open.”However, while the gritters will soon be out in full force as, locals are still reminded to take their own precautions.Mr Allen added: “As ever we ask members of the public to play their part in ensuring their vehicles are well maintained, that they plan their journeys in advance during inclement weather and that they carry equipment to help themselves should conditions deteriorate.”

title: dundee street artists to take on europe in competition
story: Dundee has been selected alongside street art centres in Italy and Spain as one of the cities to feature in a European competition.Travel the Wall will see artists from Dundee submit any of their spray paint artwork on the city’s Mary Ann Lane, with the winner bagging a trip to Barcelona.The alley, near Dundee Bus Station, contains a designated “free wall” where anyone can go to paint, mirroring spaces in cities across the world.Artists in Parma and Aberdeen will also compete on their respective free walls for a trip to Spain, while those in Barcelona will compete for a trip to Scotland or Italy.The competition is being organised by Wallspot, a body which promotes collaboration between street artists in  countries worldwide.Dundee’s involvement is being orchestrated by OpenClose, a project which has seen neglected spaces around the city transformed by artwork.Russel Pepper, a PhD student who set up OpenClose, described the competition as “awesome”.He said: “As far as I know, this is the first time Dundee has worked with other cities in Europe.”

title: dundee united fans to have chance to meet league winning stars
story: Dundee United fans will have the chance to meet heroes from the  league-winning at a special night being held in the city.Whitehall Theatre will host ‘An Evening With The Tangerine Terrors’ on Saturday November  to celebrate the th anniversary of their achievement.Former players including John Holt, Maurice Malpas, Paul Hegarty, Hamish McAlpine, Eamonn Bannon, John Reilly, Davie Dodds and Paul Sturrock will be there on the night.The former teammates will be brought back together for a night of stories and memories from from the unforgettable season # which climaxed by clinching the league title at Dens Park in a - win over Dundee.The show will have an added bit of interest as it will be hosted by Keith Haggart who is the grandson of George Fox # the former long-serving club director.Tickets can be secured on Friday via dundeebox

title: embarrassed freddy frans confident dundee united can recover
story: Dundee United defender Freddy Frans admits he felt embarrassed to have led the side during their - home defeat at the hands of Ross County which, ultimately, spelled the end for Csaba Laszlo.Frans captained the side on the day as Csaba was relieved of his duties as manager in the wake of the Tannadice hammering.His No  Laurie Ellis has taken interim charge and will likely be in the dugout as United travel to Somerset Park to face league leaders Ayr United on Saturday.And, although he is still hurting after the County calamity, Belgian centre-back Frans believes they can bounce back straight away.“People should look at themselves, we don’t need to talk about somebody , we don’t need to talk about the manager or other players,” he said.“We need to look at our own performances and I feel embarrassed.“Especially in an important game like this against one of our title rivals. I can’t remember getting beaten like this.“At half-time there was a lot of emotion, we were trying to get things straight and after the game we’re angry but what can you say  We need to look at ourselves.“It’s easy to look at others and pass the blame on but there is no use in doing that.“We need to stick together.“You always have to be confident, it’s stupid as a football player to think you can’t turn it around. You have to stay positive.“Even though it’s hard to take we have to take it on the chin and go again this weekend.”The -year-old was at a loss to explain what went wrong on Saturday as a Billy Mckay hat-trick and goals from Sean Kelly and Joshua Mullin did the damage for a United side that could only muster one of their own through Pavol Safranko on  minutes.What Frans did accept though, was they need to improvethey want to get the better of the likes of Ross County and others now above them in the race for the Championship title.The Terrors lie in fourth, five points behind leaders Ayr and Frans feels they can learn a thing or two from their promotion rivals.“Sometimes it’s hard to explain in football, you get so much confidence and then this happens. It comes from nowhere,” he added.“I think we started really well. We had a great chance at the beginning and, obviously, we miss it. We concede a stupid goal on a set-piece where we need to be smarter.“We get back into the game with a great goal and, in that moment, I thought we were OK but again we concede a stupid goal again with a cross from the side.“Even then at - it’s bad but I thought ‘look we’ve got  minutes to turn it round’ and then we concede quite early.“The red card for Stewart Murdoch finished it. It’s easy to blame it on mentality but with the goals we conceded it’s about quality as well.“It’s about being smart. That’s what theydid better on Saturday, they were more dirty, more street-wise and we’re too nice.“I can’t blame boys, especially during the week in training, for effort because we train really hard butyou see the game on Saturday it’s logical for the first thing people question to be mentality.“You can run as much as you want butyou don’t do the basics and take a hold of the ball,you don’t pick up your man, simple things like that you’ll lose the game.”Frans apologised to fans, saying: “There’s not much we can say to the supporters, just sorry. I know it’s cheap to say but there is no excuse. We’re just sorry.”

title: ernest hemingway based penguin welcomed to dundee office after maggies auction
story: Dundee-based solicitors Thorntons have welcomed a new, well-read recruit in the form of a book-themed Maggie’s penguin.The Penguin Classic sculpture, designed by Calene Scott-White, was inspired by the cover designs of Penguin books and is a replica of the Ernest Hemingway novel The Old Man and The Sea.Staff at Thorntons have affectionately given the orange and white sculpture the nickname Hemingway, after the author.The firm tweeted a picture of the penguin arriving at its office on Yeaman Shore. In its Twitter post, Thorntons said: “We’re very excited to introduce our newest team member# Hemingway the Penguin! Since he joined us yesterday morning, our team has made Hemingway most welcome in his new home.”Thorntons acquired Hemingway by paying £, at an auction held last week on the conclusion of Maggie’s Penguin Parade. The firm sponsored it during the event.In total, the Maggie’s Penguin Parade auction raised £, for Maggie’s, which supports those being treated for cancer as well as their extended family and friends.

title: ex chief demands retraction over false claim dundee port is not deep enough
story: A former chief executive of Dundee Port Authority has demanded a retraction of the “” claim the port is not deep enough for decommissioning work.A report by consultants Ernst and Young dismissed Dundee in favour of Dales Voe in Shetland because of its greater depth.However, Captain John Watson, former chief executive of the Port of Dundee, has questioned the qualications of those who wrote the report and demanded a retraction and correction from Energy Minister Paul Wheelhouse.Mr Watson also called for the report authors to “get back to the drawing board” and put Dundee back in the running.A Scottish Government spokesman said: “The outcome of the feasibility study does not impact on our support for ports, harbours and the decommissioning supply chain across Scotland, including Dundee.”

title: neil mccann backs his dundee players to handle the heat
story: Dundee will have to face a dferent kind of pressure this weekend against Kilmarnock but manager Neil McCann is backing his players to handle it once again.The Dark Blues boss was full of praise for the way his defence dealt with Hamilton’s direct approach in the second half of their - victory.Accies brought on strikers Rakish Bingham and on-loan Mason Bloomfield as they bombarded the Dundee defensive line.However, with the help of the crossbar a couple of times, Dundee held out and lted some of the heat that’s been on the manager and his team after the six straight defeats that began their season.With Killie’s attacking line of Greg Stewart, Eamonn Brophy, Jordan Jones, Chris Burke and Kris Boyd it’ll be a dferent sort of pressure the Dark Blues will have to be ready to deal with.Neil, though, expects the edginess in their defending as they homed in on their first win to be gone come Saturday.He said: “The next game will be a tough one against Kilmarnock but we enjoyed last weekend because it had been a long time coming.“Against Hamilton, I knew they would go direct, they brought Bingham on and did go more direct.“You have to deal with that – there is only so much you can do as a manager, tactically, and the players have to deal with it.“You have to be able to deal with the threat of them going direct.“There was a wee bit of edge still in their game because I’ve been saying for weeks I’d love to see them go in front and see what it did to their game.“I always knew they would still be playing with pressure but they dealt with that.“They had to deal with long balls, there were a couple of balls flashed across the goal but I thought we were well worth our three points last Saturday.”Meanwhile, a Dundee reserve side including first-teamers Jack Hamilton, Darren O’Dea, Jesse Curran and Jean Mendy were thrashed - by Dunfermline at Kelty Hearts’ New Central Park.It was Jimmy Boyle’s men’s first defeat in the Reserve League with goals from Lewis McCann, two from former Dundee United man Robbie Muirhead and second-half penalties from Tom Beadling and Myles Hippolyte counting for the Pars.The match did see a first outing for new Dee signing Grant Nelson.The -year-old from Rangers signed up with Boyle’s reserve side before the contest.

title: pacha confident dundee stars can blow out the flames this weekend
story: Kitmart Dundee Stars take the long road south today to play the first of a double header against their old BNL rivals Guildford Flames.And, on Sunday, the Surrey side will provide the opposition for thegame at Dundee Ice Arena.With just four points separating nine clubs, from second-top Cardf Devils to second-bottom Milton Keynes Lightning, Dundee are sitting comfortably in mid-table.However, coach Omar Pacha knows full points this weekend is something his Stars are long overdue.After their frustrating overtime defeats last Sunday at Lightning and at home against Devils, the Canadian is looking to reverse this trend.He said: “The hockey gods definitely owe us one, especially for our fans. They were brilliant again on Wednesday and they encouraged us all the way.“I’m pretty sure they’re satisfied with the product we’re putting out on the ice.“If we keep performing at the level we’re at, we’ll definitely give ourselves a chance to win these two games.”Pacha has also warned his players about not allowing their opponents to grab a two-goal lead.The past three games against Belfast, Milton Keynes and Cardf meant Stars had to battle back to earn points.He said: “It’s something we’re working on and we’ll have to be alert from the puck drop this weekend. It’s time we started scoring first.”Stars were dealt a fresh injury blow during their midweek game against Cardf and now have two players on the treatment table.Matt Bissonnette’s back injury is still causing the Canadian forward a problem. Added to the list is fellow-countryman Matt Marquardt.The giant offensive forward took a knock in the second period against Devils and didn’t participate in the rest of the game.The coach said: “Bissonnette is taking longer than we’d hope to get back to fitness.“We’ll be assessing Marquardt and, hopefully, we’ll have him available for this weekend.”Ahead of today#s game, Pacha said: “It’s going to be a good challenge. It’s a long drive but we should be ready for them.“We know Guildford are a fast team with skills. They score a lot of goals.“Again, we’ll have to re-evaluate ourselves for these two matches.”One player who Pacha will definitely be looking to keep his scoring run going is Jordan Cownie.The Dundonian has been finding the net on a regular basis and put in a Man-of-the-Match performance with his double against the defending champions on Wednesday.However, the -year-old’s copy book was blotted when he was sin-binned seconds into sudden death overtime, which undoubtedly contributed to Devils’ winner.Pacha was still sore about that soft hooking call but in no way blamed the young centre for his part in the defeat.The coach said with a wry smile: “I guess I’ll have to tell Cownie to stop working out and, at ft in and weighing around lbs, dragging out a guy at ft in and getting a penalty!”Sunday’s face-off is at the earlier family-friendly time of pm, with meals being served in the small bar from pm until the start of the game. The main bar is open until pm for drinks.Meanwhile, Stars’ Official Supporters Club still have a few spaces available for their annual players and fans’ Muddy Assault Course challenge on October .Entry costs £ for adults and £ for children. title: plea for extra funding to avoid loss of 40 teachers at local schools
story: The Scottish Government has been urged to step in and prevent the loss of about  teachers in Fe as schools face budget cuts.Consultation has started with staff at the kingdom’s  secondary schools.Head teachers have been told to find savings of about £. million this year and it is anticipated there will be a further £m reduction next year.About  promoted posts are expected to be scrapped this year, with the same again after the February  budget is set.North East Fe MSP Willie Rennie urged Education Secretary John Swinney to reverse what he described as “brutal” cuts.He said: “It is the SNP government’s decision to slash council budgets that has led to this whopping cut to school budgets.“The SNP claims that education is its top priority but the evidence suggests otherwise.“Taking away more than £.m from Fe secondary schools is in no way prioritising the education of our young people.“If John Swinney is true to his word he will step in to prevent the cuts to teachers and the inevitable adverse impact on education in Fe.”The area’s MP Stephen Gethins said he had asked Finance Secretary Derek Mackaythe Scottish Government could further soften the impact of austerity on local councils and schools most affected.He said: “It is easy to blame Fe Council and the Scottish Government who are having to mitigate these cuts.“Responsibility, however, lies firmly with the Tory government at Westminster and its obsession with austerity to the detriment of all public services.”David Farmer, Fe branch spokesman for the EIS teaching union, warned a vote for strike action led to similar proposals where in Scotland b eing withdrawn.A spokesman for the Scottish Government said: “Local government funding to schools is increasing and Fe Council is receiving its fair share of this, amounting to more than £m.“Together with the decision to increase its council tax by %, it has £.m more available this year to support day-to-day services such as education.”

title: private firm with profits of 1m last year hikes up cost of ninewells parking yet again
story: Visitors to Ninewells Hospital are set to fork out more cash for parking after another rise in fees was announced.Indigo Infra Dundee Ltd, which operates the facility’s car parks on behalf of NHS Tayside as part of a contract signed several years ago, will raise its daily charge by p to £. from next month.Annual staff permits are set to rise from £. to £..It follows similar hikes in recent years which have sparked anger among patients and staff.Indigo reported a £. million profit in , up .% on the previous year, due to “an increase in parking tarfs”, according to documents filed with Companies House.The company took on a contract to manage Ninewells’ parking in  on a -year deal.It would cost NHS Tayside millions of pounds to buy out the agreement, and both health and government chiefs have repeatedly ruled out such a move.Margaret Watt, recently retired honorary chairman of the Scottish Patients Association, said: “These parking companies should be ashamed of themselves.“They are targeting patients and their relatives at a very vulnerable time in their lives when people can be very unwell, or even on their final days.“Somebody should make these parking companies share these massive profits where they are needed at a time when the NHS is struggling.“The effect on hospital staff is also unacceptable .”Fraser Macpherson, Lib Dem councillor for the West End ward, which includes Ninewells, said: “These increases not only put pressure on the pockets of patients, their families and staff, it also puts pressure on side streets near the hospital.#Signing up for this contract, which still has another  years to run, was not the cleverest thing for NHS Tayside to do and they are stuck with it.”NHS Tayside said it would be inappropriate to comment.Indigo Infra Dundee Ltd had not responded to a request for comment as the Tele went to press.

title: scots comedian daniel sloss hasnt looked back since turning down student life in dundee
story: He#s travelled the world several times over, playing to thousands of fans every night and he already has two Netflix specials under his belt.At the age of , Daniel Sloss has achieved more than many comedians could hope to achieve in a letime – but he has no plans of slowing down.The prolic funnyman will be bringing his latest stand-up show X to Tayside next month, as part of the UK leg of his global tour.Born in south London but raised in Fe, Sloss said he was looking forward to being back in front of a home crowd again.“The great thing about being Scottish is that every gig is a homecoming gig, doesn’t matter what part of Scotland you’re in,” he said.“The Scots are disgustingly supportive of their own and I love it. But at the same time a lot of them remember me as the floppy haired little teenager and they won’t let me forget it. So that keeps me grounded.”Sloss got his big break as a teenager when his mum met Frankie Boyle and introduced him to her son. He started writing jokes for Boyle on Mock the Week and began performing stand-up in .He hasn’t looked back since – but it could have been very dferent had he accepted an offer to study history at Dundee University in .Sloss however thinks he made the right decision.“Oh god I would’ve been miserable,” he said. “And not because of the course or the uni, but just because I’m lazy.“I would have been a bad student and I wouldn’t have applied myself or got a decent job out of it.“I have no other skill set. I’m just good at making people laugh.“If I couldn’t do comedy I’d just continue to drink myself into an early grave. Much easier than real le.”In the past Sloss has dabbled in sitcom writing – BBC Scotland commissioned a pilot, the Adventures of Daniel, in  but a full series never emerged. Askedhe would ever bring the sitcom back, Sloss replied: “No.“The Adventures of Daniel will never, ever be brought back. I’m always working on stuff with other writers out in America, so hopefully something comes from that.“I enjoy acting. But my heart lies in straight stand-up. I just want to keep touring, get a few more Netflix specials and ultimately just get better at stand-up.”Sloss will be in Perth on November  and Dunfermline on November . His November  gig at Dundee Rep is sold out.“It’s always nice to come home,” he added.“I grew up in Fe, I live in Edinburgh. Scotland is where my home is and where I relax.“And I’m an awful tourist. I’ve been to New York  times and never once seen the Statue of Liberty.”

title: Fee introduction was a factor in recyling rate dip but just a blip insists Highland Council
story: THE controversial introduction of the fee for emptying brown bins was a factor in the arearsquos dip in recycling rates last year.But Highland Council chiefs say it was just a blip.While the level of household waste recycled nationally exceeded the amount sent to landfill for the first time, the tonnage slipped in Highland.The regionrsquos  recycling feat of . per cent dropped last year to . per cent ndash and last year a pound charge was brought in for emptying garden waste bins. This fee was increased to pound this year.The councilrsquos vice convener Allan Henderson, who also is also chairman of the environment committee, said: ldquoWhile wersquore getting better at recycling, the change to charging for brown bins has meant some garden waste being channelled into municipal waste.ldquoI believe our proposal to build a lsquomaterial recovery facilityrsquo and roll out extra brown bin coverage will reverse this slight dip.The latest figures from the Scottish Environment Protection Agencyshow that recycling rates improved at  of Scotlandrsquos  local authorities.It estimates that . per cent of waste generated in Scotland was recycled, which was an annual increase of . per cent.Scotlandrsquos environment secretary Roseanna Cunningham welcomed the figures but said more progress was needed, particularly in the cities.The biggest increases in recycling rates were in West Lothian, East Renfrewshire, Dumfries and Galloway, South Ayrshire and Aberdeen City.Ms Cunningham said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has big plans for tackling waste plastics, in particular by introducing a depositscheme, to further incentivise people to recycle.ldquoWersquove also introduced a household recycling charter for local authorities to sign up to, which is making the approach to recycling less confusing for households and creating a more consistent and efficient system for authorities.The Sepa figures show the amount of household waste generated in Scotland was . million tonnes in  ndash a decrease of , tonnes from .Saturday  Oct  : AM

title: Gaelic centre plan has backing of Inverness public
story: A SURVEY has shown that there is signicant public support for a new Gaelic cultural centre in Inverness.The research, which was carried out by the Alba Heritage Trust with the aim of establishing the level of interest in a project celebrating Gaelic heritage, was met with ldquooverwhelming backing from members of the public.Alba Heritage Trust director Alastair Forbes says the reaction has from businesses and iniduals across the board has been signicant.ldquoWe are delighted to have had so many responses to the survey, he said.ldquoThe reaction from the public and private sectors and from members of the community for the establishment of a Gaelic cultural centre has been extremely positive which has given us great confidence in moving forward with the project.Dr Blackrsquos Memorial Hall in the city centre has already been earmarked as a potential venue for the initiative ndash backed by an architectural survey.Plans for potential facilities in the centre include a Gaelic cafeacute, a retail space selling Gaelic-themed products, and language classes as well as a cultural exhibition.It would also host ceilidhs, shows and performances, as well as talks and lectures on the subject of Gaelic culture.Alba Heritage Trust director Emily Macdonald said: ldquoA cultural centre of this type would be of great benefit to the city of Inverness and the wider Highland area.ldquoIt would provide a focal point for anyone with an interest in Gaelic language and culture.ldquoThe potential impacts include promoting Gaelic language and culture, increasing Gaelic usage, encouraging community interaction, attracting further cultural events to the city, creating jobs and enhancing Invernessrsquos offering as a centre for tourism.Saturday  Oct  : AM

story: A gay pride march through the centre of Inverness has been given the go-ahead.Proud Ness, which will take place on October , has been at the centre of a bitter row after Donald Morrison, a home mission worker with the Free Church of Scotland , submitted a petition to Highland Council signed by  people opposing the event on "biblical, religious and moral grounds".In response, thousands of supporters signed counter petitions, saying gay pride was celebrated all over the world and the people of Inverness wanted to be on the right side of history.The council confirmed this morning the march can go ahead."We have notied the organisers that Highland Council and Police Scotland have no objections to the march being held as per the details in their notice of intention," the spokeswoman said.Previously, the spokeswoman said the petitions from both sides would not have a bearing on the decision process as the raised matters of concern were not sufficient reason to refuse the parade.Saturday  Oct  : AM

title: Highland Council shouldnt have to shoulder cost of Universal Credit introduction argues MP
story: Inverness and Nairn MP Drew Hendry is calling on the UK government to meet the additional burden and is also seeking an urgent meeting with Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey.It follows a similar demand from council leader Margaret Davidson who says the costs should not be met by Highland council tax and rent payers.Inverness was first chosen in  as the only place in Scotland to trial the much-criticised welfare reform which was implemented in the city two years ago and in the rest of the Highlands last year.Despite tales from claimants facing a tide of debt and dficulties ndash many of which were highlighted in the Inverness Courier ndash it is also being rolled out across the UK.But Mr Hendry described the move as ldquoshambolic and said people in the Highlands were having to subsidise the government for its failed project.ldquoDay in, day out, Highland Council staff have to deal with a system littered with inefficiencies and a host of process failures ndash costing not only more time for officers but lots more money from the councilrsquos budget, he said. ldquoIn addition to meeting administration costs, Highland Council is also having to burden the cost of rent arrears which have shot through the roof because of theof time people and landlords have to wait for payments. It simply cannot go on.According to figures obtained by Mr Hendry, the council spent pound, between - to administer universal credit but only received pound, from the government, leaving a gap of pound,.The figures also showed more than half the councilrsquos pound. million in rent arrears was directly attributable to the new system.Mr Hendry warned with nearly , people in the Highlands still to be transferred to universal credit the bill would continue to rise.Councillor Davidson also wrote to Ms McVey in August seeking full reimbursement of the costs but is still awaiting a reply.ldquoThe council continues to support claimants who are impacted by universal credit as a result of flaws in the system, Cllr Davidson said.But the councilrsquos Conservative leader Andrew Jarvie said lessons had been learned and issues ironed out.ldquoIt is easy to look at headline figures and see the situation gets blown out of all proportion, he said. ldquoPrior to universal credit, housing rent arrears were about pound million.A spokesman for the Department of Work and Pensions said support was provided for claimants as they moved to universal credit while a flexible payment system had been introduced in Scotland.ldquoRent arrears are complicated and they cannot be attributed to a single cause, he said. ldquoOur research shows that many people join universal credit with pre-existing arrears but the proportion of people with arrears falls by a third after four months on universal credit.-Drew Hendry will hold a welfare surgery on Friday for anyone struggling with benefit or welfare issues as part of the Poverty Alliancersquos Challenge Poverty Week.It will take place between noon and pm at Merkinch Community Centre.Other organisations taking part include Highland Council, Citizens Advice Bureau, Inverness Cathedral, Advocacy Highland, Employability Skills and Welfare Project, and MFR Cash for Kids.Saturday  Oct  : AM

title: Inverness streets past preserved by key heritage trail
story: The new digital heritage trail, a key part of the Inverness Townscape Heritage Project, spent the past two-and-a-half years engaging with the community around Academy Street.During that time some  heritage lsquoengagement eventsrsquo were held and people were invited to share their stories.In the end more than  came forward, representing people such as A. I. Welders Social Group, the Second Inverness Girls Brigade and the congregation and community of the East Church.Their input has brought to light a wealth of high quality content for the website, as well as opening up the rich iety of materials available in the cityrsquos museum, library and archive collections.And this new digital heritage trail was tested by stakeholders at Inverness Museum and Art Gallerylast week.Their feedback will help the developers, AOC Archaeology, refine and shape the website before it is launched on October .The site has been designed to continually evolve as more content is generated.A range of the results from the public engagement are currently on display at IMAG, including stunning detailed line drawings of Academy Street in  by Gordon Lynn.The Townscape Heritage Partnership chairman, Councillor Richard Laird, said: ldquoI am delighted to try out the website and to see how it showcases the rich iety of material that members of the public have so generously brought forward to save for generations of residents and visitors to our city.The project was run in partnership with High Le Highland and AOC Archaeology.Ian Murray, chief executive of High Le Highland, added: ldquoIt has been fascinating to hear the stories of Academy Street as told by over  iniduals who have generously contributed to the project.Saturday  Oct  : AM

title: Port cruises to best ever year
story: THE Port of Cromarty Firth recorded its best ever year in , with almost pound million in turnover, it has reported.Its annual review reports a turnover of pound. million ndash pound million higher than its previous turnover record in .A ersication from its core business of oil and gas to renewables, decommissioning and cruise and a higher number of vessels than expected resulted in the improvement. Many of the visitors have been taken by coach to hot spots such as Inverness and Loch Ness.The strong results will allow the port at Invergordon to continue to invest in major developments, such as the new quayside and laydown space, which is in the planning stages for construction through Chief executive Bob Buskie said: ldquoAt the start of , with low oil and gas prices, we knew the port had to adapt to sustain our growth and help keep local people in work.ldquoFirstly, supporting our core customers in oil and gas was a key concern.ldquoAfter the necessary consultation, we introduced a new pricing for statutory dues in January , which meant an average five per cent reduction in fees for most clients, supporting them through the downturn.ldquoSecondly, the port had to look to the future and see what we could do to help sustain jobs and growth.The cruise-liner market was a success last year, with the port being named as the busiest in Scotland. It welcomed  ships and more than , passengers mdash a  per cent increase on . The direct spend from passengers is put at pound million.The port has outlined plans to build a new multi-use berth development to provide modern facilities and to accommodate the larger cruise ships.The port also ran two workshops, in conjunction with the cruise companies and Highlands and Islands Enterprise, to help local businesses understand and work with this lucrative sector. A cruise stakeholder group was also established to help improve logistics and communication.Port board chairman Douglas Russell said hard work by its staff saw produced the record-breaking year.Saturday  Oct  : AM

title: Pressure on Highland Council to stub out unethical investments
story: HIGHLAND Council could review its stake-holding in tobacco, alcohol and weapons companies.Opposition to such selections was spelled out by Ross-shire councillor Angela MacLean amid long running anger about the ethics of the local authority investing millions of pounds in such industries while also claiming to promote ldquohealthy lestyles through council policies.Over the past  years, a small band of councillors has registered opposition to widely perceived ldquounethical investments but to no effect.Independent fund managers are employed to get the maximum . Recent figures showed the fund increased in value in - by pound. million. As of last weekend, it was valued at pound,,,..Addressing colleagues on the audit and scrutiny committee, Cllr MacLean called for a review of investment strategy. She acknowledged the need to secure the best .But she added: ldquoSome people are not happy with some of the investments and feel that perhapsitrsquos invested in tobacco or arms or things like that, itrsquos not ethically responsible.She asked whether fund trustees had any say in the choice of investments.The councilrsquos investments change on a daily basis.Recent examples of contentious choices include British American Tobacco , liqueurs firm Pernod Ricard , pubs chain Mitchells and Butlers , Japan Tobaccoand Chinarsquos second largest brewery, Tsingtao .The councilrsquos finance director Derek Yule explained that an investments sub-committee reports to a pension board which sets the strategy.ldquoIt is very dficult when some of the investment strategy seeks to invest in shares in companies not just in the UK but worldwide, he said.ldquoWhilst I totally understand some of the ethical debate, it is very dficult to draw a line sometimes.ldquoYou might take a viewhellip would you invest in banks, for example  They might not be the best investment, anyway. But I use that as an example because banks will fund these companies.ldquoItrsquos a dficult balancing act but itrsquos certainly within your rightsyou wished the pension board to look at the investment strategy.ldquoFund managers are given guidelines to work to, so that would be quite legitimate for the council to do through the pension board.According to current policy, the fund ldquorecognises that social, environmental and ethical considerations are among factors investment managers will take into account, where relevant, when selecting investments for purchase, retention or sale.However, it stresses that ldquothe overriding consideration for pension committee members is their fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and scheme members.The Scheme Advisory Board, established up by the Scottish Government to regulate such public sector pension funds, recently obtained advice from legal counsel on the duty of pensions committees.The guidance concluded that: ldquoPensions committees in Scotland owe a fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and the scheme members in general and specically in relation to investment matters.ldquoThose duties should be exercised in the best interests of the beneficiaries and in relation to investment decisions, should aim to achieve the best financial position for the fund, balancing risk andin the usual way.Saturday  Oct  : AM

title: Recovery cafe celebrates official launch in Inverness
story: Our Place ndash or Ar n-Aite in Gaelic ndash will make its money serving cappuccinos and macchiatos to the general public, pouring the proceeds back into the enterprise.Staff at the Church Street hub will be drawn from a pool of ex-prisoners who agree to work for free infor on-the-job training.And pensioners and other do-gooders will put their green fingers to good use growing as much free fruit and vegetables as the cafeacute needs to feed its hungry customers.But in a slight hiccup managers at the Signpost charity which is spearheading Our Place are having to meet with some traders who voiced concern crime could rocketa high concentration of ex-offenders are put under one roof.James Docherty from Scotlandrsquos Crime Reduction Unit which is backing the cafeacute said the tradersrsquo concerns were ldquoa symptom of social exclusion.ldquoSocially excluding people is more likely to cause a rise in crime, he said.ldquoWe run a similar project in Glasgow called Street and Arrow. Itrsquos police-led but facilitated by people from an offendersrsquo background and itrsquos a blinding success.And speaking at the opening launch Inverness and Nairn MP Drew Hendry said: ldquoPart of the plan for the Inverness Cafeacute on Church Street is to use vegetables locally-grown by those who use the cafe and those who work in it, and its customers.ldquoThis is named lsquoGrow your own communityrsquo ndash how apt. What is really being planted here though is the new generation, the seeds of the next crop of people who understand inclusion, equality, community and respect.Alan Fowler, community programmes manager for Signpost said: ldquoWe want to create an environment where therersquos no them and us.It has secured pound, from Highland Council and pound, from The Robertson Trust.Saturday  Oct  : AM

title: Retail park plan aims to avoid major unit being left empty
story: A PLANNING application has been submitted to ide one of Invernessrsquos biggest retail units in two.Hercules Unit Trust, the owner of Inverness Shopping Park, has submitted a request to Highland Council to subide the existing Homebase store.It currently occupies the largest retail unit at the park and it was announced in August that it would be one of  Homebase stores from across the UK set to close.It is thought around  jobs in Inverness alone will be lost when it shuts by early . Job losses nationally are said to be in the region of  after Homebase entered into a company voluntary arrangement following "under-performance of the business".The applicant outlines that there is no demand for the store to be re-let as a single unit and iding the unit into two would help avoid the potential for a long-term vacancy.It is thought splitting the space would make it more appealing to potential tenants.Inverness economist Tony Mackay said: "If iding the unit into two makes it more attractive then that is a good move to make."I believe one of the occupiers is likely to be another DIY store but I do not know what the other store would be."The main problem for the retail park has been the increase in online shopping. This has been the same problem for retailers in the city centre."In light of a "city first policy" which encourages businesses to establish themselves in the city centre rather than out-of-town locations, Mr Mackay does not believe this will give the retail park an unfair advantage over more central stores.He said: "More needs to be done about the problem of online shopping on retailers. For a store like Homebase people were likely to drive there to get whatever they needed."The applicant suggested that despite the "centre first" policy this move would not be a problem because no new floor space is being created.The existing floor space would simply be split into two separate retail units.Mr Mackay said: "It is not the type of store you would be likely to find in the city centre. I would be surprisedthe council were to reject this application."Mike Smith, manager of the Inverness Business Improvement District , does not support the proposal."In my personal opinion I do not think the plan should go ahead," he said."One of the restrictions of the retail park was that there were only to be single units in section  of the Town and Country Planning Act. To ide the unit into two is going against what has already been established."This is my opinion within my role as manager and not that of Bid. I would consider submitting a formal objection to the Highland Council but I would first establish the wider views of Bid before deciding the most appropriate action to take."Providing the planning application is accepted, the two new retailers would still occupy a considerably large space.The applicant recognises that the potential new occupiers would still have a larger floor space than the other existing retail units nearby.The proposal suggests that a long-term vacancy would have a negative impact on the "vitality and viability of the commercial centre."Chief executive of Inverness Chamber of Commerce Stewart Nicol agreed that iding the unit into two would be a wise move.He said: "I think it would be a sensible and pragmatic approach to take."Saturday  Oct  : AM

title: Time to tap into healthier lifestyle
story: Scottish Government ViewpointSCOTTISH Water has announced plans to roll out tap water refill points around Scotland over the next two years.Councils are being consulted to identy the best locations with the aim of having the first  Top Up Taps installed by the end of next March.The move follows the launch earlier this year of the Your Water, Your Le campaign in which the utility giant called for customers to drink tap water at home, at work and on the move as a way of reducing waste, saving themselves money and staying hydrated.Edinburgh will be the first location for a Top Up Tap with the installation going in by the end of this month outside the front of the Scottish Parliament.Other sites being considered for the initial roll-out include Inverness and Fort William.The units will be fitted with technology that will enable the company to digitally track water usage at each Top Up point.The resulting data will be used to calculate cost and plastic savings, along with the volume of water being consumed.Douglas Millican, Scottish Water chief executive, said: "Our research shows that people feel very positively towards the quality of Scotlands tap water ndash now these state-of-the-art taps can provide access to enable water drinkers to enjoy it while on the go by carrying and using refillable bottles."A national drive to encourage people to stay hydrated by drinking water from the tap in refillable bottles was set out in the Scottish Governments Programme for Government -. Environment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham said she is delighted to see it being implemented so swtly.She said: "By encouraging people to top up from the tap using refillable bottles, we will help cut down on our use of plastics and promote the benefits of hydration building on Scottish Waters Your Water, Your Le campaign."I now look forward to refilling my bottle at the Top Up Tap outside the parliament in the coming months."The Your Water, Your Le campaign aims to make tap the first choice for water drinkers wherever they are, and encourages businesses to make it readily available for staff and customers.Water samples will be tested every two minutes, on average, to ensure that quality is maintained.Licensed premises are legally bound to serve tap water on request, yet research shows Scots are uncomfortable asking, something this campaign hopes to change. Customer research by Scottish Water revealed tap is the water of choice for almost two thirds of people in Scotland , and currently over a thirdcarry reusable bottles always or often when out and about. But less than a thirdsaid theyd be happy to go into a cafeacute and ask for their bottle to be filled.On average a litre bottle of water costs about p, so topping up daily from the tap, could save pound. a day, nearly pound a year.The Top Up Taps are made from marine-grade steel and are connected to the mains water supply.* For further information visit www.yourwateryourleSaturday  Oct  : AM

title: aberdeen extremely disappointed at scott mckenna ban
story: Aberdeen are #extremely disappointed# at the two-match ban  defender Scott McKenna received following a Hampden disciplinary hearing.Centre-back McKenna was issued with a Fast Track Notice of Complaint  by the SFA for a challenge on  Odsonne Edouard during the Dons# side#s - defeat to Celtic on Saturday.McKenna#s challenge went unpunished by match referee Bobby Madden but retrospective action was taken by the governing body with a notice of complaint issued by the Scottish FA.McKenna was given the option of accepting a mandatory two-game ban or appealing.Aberdeen contested the ban which forced a fast track tribunal at Hampden today.However following the tribunal McKenna, , has been hit with a two game ban, effective immediately.Scotland international McKenna will now miss the upcoming Premiership matches against St Mirren and Hearts.It is the third third time the Dons have had an appeal for a suspension rejected recently.The Reds appealed a red card to Mikey Devlin in the - loss to Kilmarnock last month.The fast track tribunal upheld the dismissal and Devlin was hit with a one game suspension.Aberdeen also were unsuccessful in an appeal for the red card to Shaleum Logan following full-time in the - defeat of Celtic in the final Premiership game of last season.Logan was subsequently suspended for the first three domestic games of this season.An Aberdeen FC statement read: #The Fast Track Notice of Complaint issued to Scott McKenna by the Scottish FA has this afternoon been proven.#As a result Scott will now face a two match suspension, effective immediately.#The club is extremely disappointed with this outcome.#

title: firm calling for details on campus
story: The architects behind a major sports hub are frustrated by a local authority’s lack of communication over plans for its own facilities.Lippe Architects and Planners in Inverurie is in charge of plans for the new £ million privately-funded Garioch Sports Centre, which was given the go-ahead by Aberdeenshire councillors this year.Meanwhile, Aberdeenshire Council is working on the new £ million Inverurie Community Campus, which will replace the existing academy.But Lippe Architects and Planners director Willie Lippe is frustrated that the council has not claried its plans for new sports facilities at the campus.Mr Lippe has said the firm cannot move forward with plans for the Garioch Sports Centre until it knows what facilities the community campus will include, as they do not want to duplicate pitches or courts or leave a gap in the facilities in Inverurie.Mr Lippe said: “The fact that we have not received any details from Aberdeenshire Council about the sports facilities for the Inverurie Community Campus has certainly delayed our decision-making.“The implication has been that we are unsure what plans we should move forward with.“For example, we are very keen to improve athletics facilities in Inverurie however, we would not provide this at the sports centrewe knew that the campus was offering them.”He said he is concerned that not enough thought is being put into sports provision for children.He said: “In this day and age, providing plenty of exercise opportunities for children should be a priority.“It is very frustrating. We want to provide a fantastic iety of sport for Inverurie.“I would love to see a decision being made for the sports provisions at the campus.”An Aberdeenshire Council spokesman said: “A report into the surface of the pitches at Inverurie Community Campus is being prepared for consideration by the Garioch Area Committee.“We have followed a very open process in communicating the details of this important project, which is progressing well, and will continue to provide community updates as further details are confirmed.”

title: girls brigade groups across n east toast double anniversary
story: Members of the Girls# Brigade have joined together to celebrate the organisation’s milestone anniversary.Leaders of the Aberdeen branch of Girls’ Brigade have marked both the th birthday of the worldwide organisation and the th of the north-east ision. vw, px"  Members past and present attended the celebration in the Wellington Hotel in Nigg, honouring the work done by the volunteers over the years.Current Girls’ Brigade officer in the th ision, Angela Ritchie said: “We are a very successful ision of the Girls’ Brigade with  companies.“The success of the organisation and the ision is down to the commitment and dedication of the leaders involved.“They volunteer their time generously to the girls in their companies and ensure they have a fun, well-balanced programme to follow each week.“We all know each other really well so it was a great chance to catch up.” vw, px"  Currently there are  Girls’ Brigade groups in Aberdeen though at one point there were more than  operating in the city.The  groups within the Aberdeen ision include the th in Northfield, th in Woodside, st Portlethen, rd in Kincorth and th in Cove Bay.Honorary isional vice president and ex-captain of the st Aberdeen company, -year-old Edith Mowat – who has been involved with Girls’ Brigade for the last  years – joined the celebration as the longest standing volunteer.The mum-of-one said: “I joined when I was around  years old, and there wasn’t much for girls to do in the area.“A woman called Mary-Jane Haye helped to set up the ision – she was a kind but very strict lady – and we were called maids-in-waiting.”Edith left to raise her daughter Leslie, who also joined the Girls’ Brigade at age three.She said: “I eventually worked through the ranks until I got married and fell pregnant. Back then it was just expected that you would leave when you started a family.“However when I came back I became vice-president of the Grampian region and stayed for six years.”Edith, of Aberdeen city centre, reflected on the changes she had seen in the Girls’ Brigade over the years.She said: “It has definitely changed – the leaders aren’t as strict as Mary was – but we still learn how to work together and do things together.“With so many churches closing we must make the effort to keep going, to keep a place open for those people to go to.”The Girls’ Brigade in Scotland now has  companies serving more than , members in the communities of Scotland.All Girls’ Brigade companies are affiliated to local churches and are an integral part of both church and local community.Tanya Chapman, vice president of the Aberdeen ision as well as captain of th ision, has been attending Girls’ Brigade for more than  years.The -year-old said: “I’ve done a lot of dferent things in Girls’ Brigade, I’ve been really lucky.“We have seen a lot of change but all in line with society really – for example when we dance it used to be to someone playing the piano, but now it’s with a Bluetooth speaker.“I met two of my best friends at Girls’ Brigade.“I went to Northfield Academy and I was quite shy, so while school helped me academically, Girls’ Brigade helped me with confidence.“The event was really nice to catch up with people, especially ones who have left the organisation.“I have two daughters who both attend so I don’t think I will be leaving any time soon.”The rd Girls’ Brigade in Aberdeen have this year entered the Evening Express CommunitEE Chest competition.The group of girls, who meet weekly in Kincorth, hope to win a slice of the cash to put towards craft supplies and new equipment.

title: nursery helps spruce up hospice playroom
story: Nursery pupils helped to bring a splash of colour to an Aberdeen hospice as they opened a new playroom.Children from the Little Acorn Nursery visited Roxburghe House in Aberdeen to officially open its newly-refurbished playroom after helping to raise £, for its transformation. vw, px"  The room, now complete with toys, games and an interactive television screen, is now available for patients of all ages and relatives of older patients.After completing a sponsored walk along the Beach Esplanade, the pupils donated to the room’s revamp to join the efforts of the Friends of Roxburghe House Grampian charity.The revamp also benefited from a donation from the hospice’s SPAR store. vw, px"  Treasurer of the group Peter Clark said: “We identied the play area as being in need of refurbishment two years ago so it has been a long time in the making.“The donations from SPAR and the Little Acorns nursery have helped to transform the room.“Though Roxburghe House is primarily for adults, there are children who stay here and many who visit so this can provide some respite for them.#Roxburghe House’s SPAR also contributed to the appeal by donating £, accrued by the p bag charge.When it came to redesigning the formerly plain room, NHS activities co-ordinator Liz McDonald conducted research.She said: “I’ve been involved in the project from the start and at times it felt like it would never be finished so it is great to see it being used.“I visited playrooms in the Royal Aberdeen Children’s Hospital and CLAN to see what we could try, and we asked ex-service users and their relatives for their opinions.“We made it colourful to attract the little children but we added the ‘pod’ chair for the older children. It has chargers nearby and blocks out the sound around you, so it will be good for when they are having a hard time and just want to get away from it all.Henry McBain, , cut the ceremonial ribbon – with child-friendly scissors – and said: “I like the Lego the best.” vw, px"

title: spark lights the way to africa for aberdeen writers book
story: An Aberdeen writer has published a book exploring African connections within Scottish literature.Shane Strachan has released a collection of short fiction, titled Nevertheless: Sparkian Tales in Bulawayo, based on novelist Muriel Spark’s six years in the African city.Using archives at the National Library of Scotland including Spark’s handwritten essays, correspondence and possessions, Shane has written a contemporary take on her experiences.The protagonist is a Scottish doctor who unknowingly traces the same steps as Spark while in Bulawayo – Zimbabwe’s second city which has been twinned with Aberdeen since .Shane, who has a PhD in creative writing from Aberdeen University, was inspired by his own impressions of the city where he worked with the National Gallery of Zimbabwe on an arts-in-health project in Lady Rodwell Maternity Hospital in  and  – the same hospital where Spark gave birth to her son in .He said: “I have been to Bulawayo twice now and I think there are more similarities with Aberdeen and Bulawayo than people think, especially in terms of our industrial backgrounds.“It is a beautul place and the people there are wonderful, even in the face of poverty.”He added: “I think the cities are similar as well in the sense of there are many creative people there, as in Aberdeen, who struggle to be heard ahead of bigger and more well-known cities.”Shane will launch the book formally on October  at the Suttie Arts Space in Aberdeen Royal Infirmary at an exhibition of new work created by the Zimbabwean artists he worked with in .The book, published by Bulawayo-based publisher amaBooks, is available to buy online, with all profit from sales of the book being donated to the Lady Rodwell Maternity Hospital in Bulawayo.

title: 034ex0510eea_story__1 fn 2
story: Jamie Watt has urged Banks o’ Dee to grasp their chance to make Evening Express Aberdeenshire Cup history.The Junior Superleague champions take on Cove Rangers tonight at Harlaw Park in the final of the Shire Cup.The trophy was first played for in  and has never been won by a Junior side.Although Aberdeen University did lt the cup in  , they were not a Junior side at the time.Dee co-manager Watt, who’s in charge at Spain Park along with Tommy Forbes, wants to see his side embrace their opportunity to make history.He said: “History is there for us, we want to grasp that.“We’re a Junior team and you’d expect us to be just competing in the first and second rounds and then going out.“But we’ve built something special here and we know that, we keep asking them to perform in the games with Highland League teams and the boys keep turning up.“History is definitely there and it puts the club on the map as well, so fingers crossed we can get the result.“I’ve been emphasising to the boys that it would be huge for the clubwe could win this cup.“Just getting to the final is massive. I played Highland League for a long time and this is a hard final to get to.“So to go that next step and win the cup would be huge.“It would be a big reward for Brian Winton, the president, and the committee because the people behind the scenes do a lot and it’s them who get the reward.“Me and Tommy Forbes have a good team and they know they are a good team – but to go that extra step and beat Cove to win the cup would be fantastic.”Watt has stepped into management this season alongside Forbes after Sandy McNaughton stepped down at the end of last season.Watt says it would be a dream to win his first trophy in management tonight.He added: “I’m a born winner, I love winning and hate losing.“As a manager it’s completely dferent standing on the sidelines.“But I’ve enjoyed management so far, everything has been great.“If this was to be the first trophy on the board it would be a dream in a cup of this magnitude.”On their road to the final Dee have beaten Inverurie Locos, Aberdeen Reserves and Turrf United. Watt says they will have taken confidence from those results, but doesn’t expect it to be easy against Cove.He said: “We do take confidence from the results we’ve had in the cup this year and in the last two seasons in the Shield.“Apart from the finals where we lost we’ve had good results against pretty much everyone.“Cove’s the only team that we haven’t really beaten and we only played them in last season’s Shield final.“But we’ll go into this final confident, looking for a good performance and we’ll see what happens.“We know they’re dominating the Highland League – they are the best team in the Highland League and they’ll want to stop our run in the cup.”
